urn:contentItem:6GRX-BGT3-RT4B-G304-00000-00Is Canada's tornado season over? Experts say not yet, despite low numbers in Ontario2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Is Canada's tornado season over? Experts say not yet, despite low numbers in OntarioDominik Kurek

A year after Canada experienced near-record numbers of tornadoes, we're trending to have a relatively low one, particularly in Ontario, and much lower than what we've experienced in recent years.

David Sillis, director with Western University's Northern Tornadoes Project, said via email the summer so far "has been well below normal as far as tornado activity, particularly in Ontario."

In 2025 (as of Sept. 11), the team has confirmed 64 tornadoes in Canada, including 19 in Ontario, Sillis said.

During all of 2024, there were 129 tornadoes confirmed in Canada and 60 in Ontario. The all-time national record was set in 2022 with 131 confirmed tornadoes.

Last year also experienced the longest tornado season on record, lasting 240 days, with the first tornado reported in Malden Centre, Ont. on March 16 and the last one in Fergus, Ont. on Nov. 10.

The first tornado of 2025 reportedly occurred on April 12 in Rolling Hills, Alta.

Historical tornado data in Canada

Over the last few years, NTP confirmed the following number of tornadoes across Canada:

2024 - 1292023 - 902022 - 1312021 - 1272020 - 1102019 - 802018 - 1042017 - 71

Based on a 30-year period between 1991 and 2020, the average number of tornadoes per year is 64.9 in Canada and 18.5 in Ontario, Sillis said.

The NTP team is investigating why some years are less active, in terms of tornadoes, than others, with Sillis saying there are many factors involved.

Possible reasons for fewer tornadoes this season

Environment Canada couldn't provide a definitive answer as to why we're experiencing fewer tornadoes this year, but offered a hypothesis.

Meteorologist Steven Flisfeder said there are two possible causes why Ontario, and particularly southern Ontario, are experiencing fewer tornadoes this year.

One is that this summer has been dominated by high-pressure systems, which are typically associated with clear skies.

"That would have the tendency to inhibit any kind of storms, any kind of convection, which would lead to lightning, which would lead to potential thunderstorms, which would lead to potential tornadoes," Flisfeder said.

"That high pressure, which was very strong, very persistent throughout the summer, is a possible reason why there were fewer tornadoes than we normally see in a typical year."

The second possibility is related to all the forest fire smoke we've experienced this year, particularly in June and July.

"There was a lot of smoke in the atmosphere, which has a tendency to reduce solar heating, which would help reduce the potential for thunderstorm initiation as well," Flisfeder said.

This is just a hypothesis, he added, noting a definitive answer would require further research.

Is tornado season over yet? Expert outlook

Sillis expects the number of confirmed tornadoes to climb before the year is out.

The NTP team is still reviewing satellite images from Canada's vast boreal forest, which could turn up more tornadoes from this summer that had not been reported yet due to the area's low population density.

"So, the numbers from this summer will likely go up," he said, and tornado season is likely not over yet.

"I suspect we haven't seen the end of the tornado season in Ontario, or Canada, quite yet. In fact, we've got quite a warm-up in the long-range forecast for southern Ontario, and that typically means higher potential for severe storms," he added.

More information on tornadoes in Canada is available on the NTP website.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RS97-72HJ-00000-00August fires devastated a tenth of Galicia's Natura Network2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisAugust fires devastated a tenth of Galicia's Natura Network


The magnitude of the environmental catastrophe caused by the August fires in Galicia was intuited and the data from the European Copernicus system have confirmed it. The flames devastated a tenth of the entire Galician territory included in the Natura Network, a total of 37,819 hectares, a sad record in the 21-year history of this figure of environmental protection in the community. The data was released on Tuesday by the environmental association Adega after requesting it from the forest fire information network that depends on the European Commission. The figure coincides with the estimates of the Xunta, taking into account that the Galician president, Alfonso Rueda, estimated in about 120,000 hectares burned and the Ministry of Environment admits that a third of this destruction (about 40,000) corresponds to protected areas.


According to Copernicus data released by the ecologists, this affection of fire to 10% of the Galician network of natural areas has been "the most extensive of the century" and triples the previous record of 2011. In Ourense, the flames burned more than half of the Massif Central and the Bidueiral de Montederramo, a birch forest of enormous ecological and historical importance, as it was the scene of the adventures of Romasanta, the werewolf that shocked Spain in the nineteenth century. The fires also devastated 20% of Pena Trevinca, almost 15% of Pena Maseira, and 7.5% of the Serra da Enciña da Lastra. In Lugo, 5,389 hectares of the Ancares-Courel Special Area of Conservation (ZEC) were burned, more than 5% of its surface.
The environmental association Adega claims to the Xunta "means and resources" to regenerate these territories that are "home to very sensitive and endangered species such as the bear, the golden eagle or endemic flora". "The ecosystem services provided by these areas to society (water regulation, carbon absorption, erosion control, food supply ...) will take years to recover," warns the organization.
Adega criticizes the lack of data from the Xunta. In his view, the "opacity and misinformation practiced by the Regional Ministries of Environment and Rural Affairs during this wave of fires was matched by their laziness and inoperativeness". And recalls the "regrettable" statements of the president of the Xunta, Alfonso Rueda, when he stressed that they had burned mostly "stones and brush": "They are an example of a worrying ignorance and an unacceptable environmental trumpism".
The Department of the Environment admits that a third of the total burned area (120,000 hectares, according to Rueda in his appearance in Parliament) belong to the Natura Network, although he emphasizes that this is provisional data and asks for "caution". As a measure of restoration of these areas, the department of Ángeles Vázquez cites the aid that has been approved for municipalities and associations of forests to "replace structural elements of trails and marked routes; fix infrastructure and facilities for interpretation of the natural environment; or restore elements of recreational areas" in protected natural areas.
On the other hand, the organization Ecoloxistas en Acción presented this Tuesday its first report on the state of the Natura 2000 Network in Galicia. The first delivery focuses on the province of Pontevedra and appreciates in these spaces a "serious environmental deterioration". The two areas analyzed, the A Ramallosa intertidal complex and the Ulla-Deza river system, lack specific management plans. The study of Ecoloxistas en Acción also claims that the mountain ranges of A Groba and O Suído should be protected under this community figure. Galicia is at the bottom of the list in Spain in terms of the percentage of territory integrated in the Natura Network. In 2011, the government of Alberto Núñez Feijóo began to process a proposal for an extension that included, among other places, these two mountainous areas, but it was never approved despite the demands of the European authorities.

urn:contentItem:6FYB-NM73-S95B-P26F-00000-00Research in the Area of Artificial Intelligence Reported from Gebze Technical University (Explainable Artificial Intelligence to Unveil Intrinsic Characteristics of Conditioning Factors Governing Forest Fire Susceptibility)2025-06-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCEResearch in the Area of Artificial Intelligence Reported from Gebze Technical University (Explainable Artificial Intelligence to Unveil Intrinsic Characteristics of Conditioning Factors Governing Forest Fire Susceptibility)


2025 JUN 02 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News -- New research on artificial intelligence is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting from Gebze Technical University by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires are typically triggered by natural factors or human negligence and accidents, spreading across vast areas and causing extensive damage to vegetation, wildlife, and ecosystems."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Gebze Technical University: "Machine learning algorithms have recently become important tools for their efficiency in generating high-quality wildfire susceptibility maps in the literature. Despite their success in achieving promising thematic accuracies, they are typically criticized for their black box structure and their limited ability to interpret the resulting susceptibility maps. This study aims to address these limitations by exploring the inherent characteristics of geospatial covariates controlling the wildfire phenomena with local and global underlying factors of wildfire phenomena with the application of explainable artificial intelligence (XAI). For this purpose, three ensemble machine learning algorithms, including random forest, XGBoost, and NGBoost, were initially inputted with 11 conditioning factors to produce wildfire susceptibility maps. The internal mechanisms of these models were then interpreted using global and local XAI techniques. The results showed that the NGBoost had the highest predictive performance with an overall accuracy of 81.42%, and outperformed the other algorithms by approximately 5% to 8%."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The global explainability analysis with the SHAP technique revealed that topographical parameters, such as elevation and valley depth, were the most influential factors in wildfire susceptibility. On the other hand, local analyses conducted with the LIME technique for three randomly selected instances highlighted the significant influence of parameters such as elevation, wind speed, and valley depth on individual wildfire cases."
For more information on this research see: Explainable Artificial Intelligence to Unveil Intrinsic Characteristics of Conditioning Factors Governing Forest Fire Susceptibility. The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, 2025,XLVIII-M-6-2025():281-287. (The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences - http://www.isprs.org/publications/archives.aspx). The publisher for The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences is Copernicus Publications.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.5194/isprs-archives-XLVIII-M-6-2025-281-2025.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting A. Teke, Gebze Technical University, Department of Geomatics Engineering, 41400 Gebze, Kocaeli, Turkiye. Additional authors for this research include T. Kavzoglu.
Keywords for this news article include: Gebze Technical University, Algorithms, Artificial Intelligence, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

During all of 2024, there were 129 tornadoes confirmed in Canada and 60 in Ontario. The all-time national record was set in 2022 with 131 confirmed tornadoes.

Last year also experienced the longest tornado season on record, lasting 240 days, with the first tornado reported in Malden Centre, Ont. on March 16 and the last one in Fergus, Ont. on Nov. 10.

The first tornado of 2025 reportedly occurred on April 12 in Rolling Hills, Alta.

Historical tornado data in Canada

Over the last few years, NTP confirmed the following number of tornadoes across Canada:

2024 - 1292023 - 902022 - 1312021 - 1272020 - 1102019 - 802018 - 1042017 - 71

Based on a 30-year period between 1991 and 2020, the average number of tornadoes per year is 64.9 in Canada and 18.5 in Ontario, Sillis said.

The NTP team is investigating why some years are less active, in terms of tornadoes, than others, with Sillis saying there are many factors involved.

Possible reasons for fewer tornadoes this season

Environment Canada couldn't provide a definitive answer as to why we're experiencing fewer tornadoes this year, but offered a hypothesis.

Meteorologist Steven Flisfeder said there are two possible causes why Ontario, and particularly southern Ontario, are experiencing fewer tornadoes this year.

One is that this summer has been dominated by high-pressure systems, which are typically associated with clear skies.

"That would have the tendency to inhibit any kind of storms, any kind of convection, which would lead to lightning, which would lead to potential thunderstorms, which would lead to potential tornadoes," Flisfeder said.

"That high pressure, which was very strong, very persistent throughout the summer, is a possible reason why there were fewer tornadoes than we normally see in a typical year."

The second possibility is related to all the forest fire smoke we've experienced this year, particularly in June and July.

"There was a lot of smoke in the atmosphere, which has a tendency to reduce solar heating, which would help reduce the potential for thunderstorm initiation as well," Flisfeder said.

This is just a hypothesis, he added, noting a definitive answer would require further research.

Is tornado season over yet? Expert outlook

Sillis expects the number of confirmed tornadoes to climb before the year is out.

The NTP team is still reviewing satellite images from Canada's vast boreal forest, which could turn up more tornadoes from this summer that had not been reported yet due to the area's low population density.

"So, the numbers from this summer will likely go up," he said, and tornado season is likely not over yet.

"I suspect we haven't seen the end of the tornado season in Ontario, or Canada, quite yet. In fact, we've got quite a warm-up in the long-range forecast for southern Ontario, and that typically means higher potential for severe storms," he added.

More information on tornadoes in Canada is available on the NTP website.

urn:contentItem:6G2S-6G83-RRSC-33CD-00000-00Researchers from Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Military Medicine (Controlled Burn: Managing the "forest Fire" of Leaving a Professional Identity In Medical ...)2025-06-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisMILITARY MEDICINEResearchers from Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Military Medicine (Controlled Burn: Managing the "forest Fire" of Leaving a Professional Identity In Medical ...)


2025 JUN 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Military Medicine. According to news reporting originating in Bethesda, Maryland, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Professional identity formation is central to physicians' identity over their full careers. There is little guidance within military service on how to leave careers as clinician educator faculty in graduate medical education programs."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, "The objective of our study was to explore how leaving this community of practice (COP) affects a clinician educator's professional identity. We used reflexive thematic analysis with Communities of Practice as a sensitizing construct. Fifteen semi-structured interviews were conducted among active-duty clinician educators at the point of their retirement from the military. Interview questions focused participants' lived experiences as clinician educators and professional identity changes leading to and resulting from the decision to retire. We found the clinician educators' journey through a time of professional transition led to three connected themes: Loss Precedes Growth, Fallow Season-Liminal Space, and New Growth. The experiences of military clinician educators retiring from active duty demonstrate how leaving one COP emanates across a range of professional identities. In addition, the decision to leave a professional COP can lead to a sense of disloyalty to that community. Normalizing this transition in a way that honors the community's values offers the opportunity to enable the decision to retire."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Understanding retirement as a process that first involves identity loss, followed by the discomfort of a liminal space before achieving new growth creates the opportunity to engage in rituals that celebrate the service of departing community members, releasing them to grow into new identities."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Controlled Burn: Managing the "forest Fire" of Leaving a Professional Identity In Medical Education. Journal of Continuing Education in the Health Professions, 2025;45(2):78-84. Journal of Continuing Education in the Health Professions can be contacted at: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Two Commerce Sq, 2001 Market St, Philadelphia, PA 19103, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell - www.wiley.com/; Journal of Continuing Education in the Health Professions - onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1554-558X)

McMains, Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Dept. of Surgery, 4301 Jones Bridge Rd, Bethesda, MD 20814, United States. Additional authors for this research include Steven J. Durning and Holly S. Meyer.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1097/ceh.0000000000000576. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6FWD-JX13-RV14-B3BM-00000-00SIERRA PACIFIC INDUSTRIES TO PAY FOR DAMAGES CAUSED BY FOREST FIRE IN EL DORADO COUNTY2025-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisSIERRA PACIFIC INDUSTRIES TO PAY FOR DAMAGES CAUSED BY FOREST FIRE IN EL DORADO COUNTYStates News ServiceSACRAMENTO, Calif.

The following information was released by the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of California:

Sierra Pacific Industries (SPI) has agreed to pay $204,284.42 to resolve the United States' claim for damages resulting from a 2021 wildfire that burned about 29acres, including National Forest System lands on the Eldorado National Forest, Acting U.S. Attorney Michele Beckwith announced today.

The wildfire, known as the "Cold Fire," ignited on Jan. 19, 2021, on SPI land in El Dorado County. U.S. Forest Service fire investigators determined that the fire originated from one of SPI's timber slash piles that escaped containment during a wind event.

"Our office will continue to hold individuals and corporations responsible for damages caused by wildfires," said Acting U.S. Attorney Beckwith. "Every fire impacting federal lands, no matter the size, is a priority."

"These settlements are essential in restoring our landscapes after wildfires," said U.S. Forest Service Pacific Southwest Acting Regional Forester Jason Kuiken.

The investigation was conducted with the U.S. Forest Service. Assistant U.S. Attorney Tara Amin handled the case for the U.S. Attorney's Office.

The claims resolved by the settlement are allegations only and there has been no determination of liability.

urn:contentItem:6GTK-66V3-RXWY-J1MJ-00000-00OPINION: Charlie Kirk's assassination forces everyone into politics - The Suffolk Journal2025-09-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1OPINION: Charlie Kirk's assassination forces everyone into politics - The Suffolk JournalCorey DeCristofaro

Charlie Kirk's assassination's place in the news cycle took center stage for much longer than some believe it should have. Political violence is a very real issue in America, fueled in part by the prevalence of hate speech and the availability of weapons, two things that the New York Times cites as things Kirk protected. 

To many, in the wake of Kirk's death, this presented a form of irony that could not go ignored. This irony has been invoked to claim that Kirk had incited his own assassination. To others, this does not matter in the grand scheme of things, claiming that the tragic loss of human life should always be mourned, no matter the beliefs of the victim. 

This debate, along with the graphic footage that circulated on social media platforms such as X directly after the shooting, caused Kirk's death to spark large-scale political engagement to a degree that is unusual, even for events of this caliber.

NPR cites the graphic footage that a large number of people were exposed to as a possible spark that lit the reactionary forest fire of the internet's response. 

"Seeing content like the videos of the Kirk shooting, or another video that circulated widely this month showing the fatal stabbing of a Ukrainian refugee in Charlotte, N.C., does have consequences for viewers. Those include heightened emotions, feelings of fear and vulnerability, and calls for revenge," said Nicole Hemmer, a political historian at Vanderbilt University.

The responses indicated in this article could be seen in the Instagram stories of people who weren't commonly posting about politics immediately after the shooting. Responses varied widely, from some calling for support for Kirk's family despite his beliefs, to others refusing to grieve for someone they claimed did not support their right to exist. The latter group typically called out the names of other people recently killed by political violence and the lack of media response to those events.

The most striking part of this debate was the sheer number of people who got involved. One could find people who hadn't posted on their story in years using that platform to share their stance. Why were so many people who typically took apolitical stances suddenly engaging in politics?

One possible reason is the sheer reach this tragedy had. Once the graphic video circulated and extremists from both sides of the aisle began to share their opinion on the matter, apolitical people were likely emotionally affected. As stated before, graphic videos like the footage of Kirk's assassination spark intense emotions. 

This fact, paired with extremist commentary that many apolitical people found offensive, likely caused a perceived need to arise among apolitical people to share their own less extreme views on the matter. Thus, outpourings of sympathy were fueled by both extreme takes by the far left and the far right. 

These likely well-intentioned calls for sympathy instead of increased infighting were then viewed by those with political views who are usually quite private about the matter. These people were then encouraged to post their views, which varied widely. Some expressed the idea that Kirk was one of many politically motivated deaths and that others, perhaps those that didn't have any association with politics, who could have incensed their murders, deserve just as much recognition and grief by the general public as Kirk. Others claimed that some were unjustly celebrating Kirk's death.

It is true that the news coverage and the general impact of Kirk's death was astounding, even leading to the suspension of Jimmy Kimmel's show, "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" This impact is not typically seen for victims of gun violence, even if they are high-profile. 

For example, the assassination of democratic congresswoman Melissa Hortman was not given the same amount of national attention. For example, flags were not lowered in response to this, while they were for Kirk. The assassination, which occurred in June of this year, did not garner nearly as much attention on social media, likely a reason for the lack of discussion and coverage nationally.

Regardless of your political position, it is clear that Kirk's assassination was a rare event that had almost everyone discussing politics. It is not every day that apolitical community members and people who like to stay private about politics weigh in on the national situation. For this reason, the impacts of Kirk's death will likely continue to make national news and impact public personalities on both sides of the aisle for some time to come.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9W53-RXXX-847F-00000-00Three-way meeting this Thursday to address the Forest Brigades labor dispute between hope and caution2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisThree-way meeting this Thursday to address the Forest Brigades labor dispute between hope and caution


Tragsa, the Community of Madrid and the works committee of the Forestry Brigades that work in the region contracted by the public company will hold this Thursday the first three-way meeting since the beginning of the indefinite strike to try to find solutions to the labor conflict of these workers.


The three parties have been summoned at 11.00 am at Tragsa's facilities in Leganés to address the claims of this group of workers, hired by the public company after receiving an order in 2022 from the Community of Madrid and which expires in December.
A three-way meeting to which the workers' works council --- formed by the unions UGT, Firet and CGT --- goes with the hope of being able to make progress in labor improvements but also with a lot of caution.
"We are cautious, we understand that it is a first contact," Julio Chana, a member of the works council for CGT, told Europa Press about what is the first meeting between the three parties in six months of demands by the workers.
His colleague Rafael Fernández, from UGT, has assured that they are "expectant" because they do not know what the company Tragsa -whose majority shareholder is the Sociedad Estatal de Participaciones Industriales (SEPI), which depends on the Ministry of Finance- can raise at this meeting.
"We understand that in this meeting there is still much to talk about, we hope that there is much to be agreed, and that it will be the beginning of the opening of a negotiating table, so that we start to bring closer agreements among all of us, above all which will be beneficial for the whole forest fire department and therefore for all the citizens", he said in statements made to Europa Press.
Although they are hopeful of being able to advance their demands, they also demand "firm commitments and certainties" and not promises. "The red line is that we need signed agreements," said Chana.
From the Community of Madrid, which had already proposed that three-way negotiating table and sees "fair" labor claims, have also been hopeful about the outcome that may have the meeting whose celebration, in any case, see positive. "All hope placed," said Wednesday the Minister of Environment, Agriculture and Interior of the Community of Madrid, Carlos Novillo.
The regional government has already confirmed to Tragsa its intention to renew the order for the functions of prevention, assessment, surveillance, detection and support to the Fire Department of the Community of Madrid in tasks of extinction of forest fires and in certain interventions related to adverse meteorological episodes.
The new one, which would come into force in 2026, will include improvements such as an increase in the budget item by 4 million euros to reach a total above 32 million per year, as well as the consolidation of more than 425 troops who will be throughout the year, so that it will end with the temporary hires from May next year.
"Also, even improve some of the complements for their performance in inclement weather," said the counselor, who in any case stresses that "there is room for improvement".
In any case, both the Community and Tragsa remain entrenched in their positions as to who is competent to implement these improvements. The regional government defends that it cannot negotiate these improvements for the workers as it is not competent in a sectorial collective agreement, as a report requested for this purpose to the Directorate General of Labor points out. Specifically, the report, consulted by Europa Press, states that, although Tragsa "is not entitled to negotiate" this sectoral collective agreement, it can negotiate "its own company agreement".
Specifically, the personnel of the Forestry Brigades of Madrid are governed by the Sectoral Agreement for the Prevention, Surveillance and Extinction of Forest Fires of the Community of Madrid, an autonomous sectoral collective agreement on which, according to Tragsa, "is not entitled to negotiate".
As Tragsa's own president, Jesús Casas, recently explained, with the 2022 order, the public company took charge of this service in the region, "subrogating it with the agreement that existed in the Community of Madrid and with the personnel that already existed". In any case, Tragsa has emphasized that if labor improvements are included in the new order, it will apply them.
Among the proposals put forward in recent weeks, the works committee has already expressed its clear rejection of the possibility of joining the agreement of the public company for the state Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF). Although the Community considers that it is "perfectly legal", the workers believe that "it is clearly not an option" and would generate "legal insecurity".
DEMANDS
The works council denounces the precarious and temporary situation in which they carry out their work and demands labor improvements for the collective and the negotiation of the collective agreement, which has not been revised since 2008.
Among other demands, they ask to update salaries, frozen since 2010, to take into account the danger, hardship and toxicity involved in their work - they are not protected against carcinogenic agents -, and to put an end to the temporary nature of their work - 40% of the workforce is working four months a year.
They also demand improvements in some bases that have been abandoned for 20 years or that Law 5/2024, approved on November 8, 2024, be applied, something that the Community of Madrid does not do.
They are about 500 forest firefighters -about 350 in the off-season- who work in the Community of Madrid but are hired by the public company Tragsa.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RFY3-S6W0-70JB-00000-00The puma in Argentina: an essential predator in danger2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisThe puma in Argentina: an essential predator in danger


Every August 30 is celebrated as International Puma Day, a date that invites us to think about the conservation of one of the great predators of the Americas. The Puma concolor, also known as mountain lion or American lion, extends from Alaska to the south of Argentina and Chile, being the wild mammal with the largest distribution area in the continent.


In Argentina, this feline plays a fundamental role as a top predator, regulating the populations of wild prey such as the guanaco. Its presence is essential to maintain the ecological balance, since its remains feed scavenger species, such as the Andean condor. However, their relationship with livestock activity has generated conflicts in various rural regions of the country.
The scarcity of natural prey in some ecosystems has led the puma to hunt sheep and goats. This has provoked reprisals by producers, including illegal hunting and poisoning of these animals. To reverse this situation, organizations such as WCS Argentina are promoting non-lethal coexistence strategies.
Coexistence strategies
Among the strategies that stand out are the use of night lights, sound emitters, protection dogs and Wildlife Friendly® certification. The latter improves the value of products such as merino wool and mohair, fostering a more harmonious relationship between producers and the puma.
Threats to the puma
The puma also faces various threats, such as the loss and fragmentation of its habitat, the advance of the agricultural frontier, road killings and harassment by domestic dogs. In the province of Mendoza, the feline is legally protected, which prohibits its hunting or possession as a pet.
History of International Puma Day
The date of August 30 was established in honor of a rescue operation that took place in 2009 in the Pumakawa reserve, in Córdoba. At that time, a forest fire endangered the lives of several specimens. Since then, the reserve has worked on conservation campaigns that include the closure of breeding grounds for hunting, the prohibition of trophy imports and coordinated actions with local producers.
Status of the puma population
According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature, the total puma population on the continent is estimated to be less than 50,000 and is on a downward trend. In view of this reality, specialists stress the importance of conserving healthy habitats and promoting a harmonious coexistence between wildlife and human activities.
The post The puma in Argentina: an essential predator in danger first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

July 23rd, 2025 ( Al Jazeera English - Delivered by Newstex )

At least 10 firefighters and rescue workers were killed and 14 others injured while battling a wildfire in Turkiye's northwestern Eskisehir province, authorities said, as several fires rage in central and western areas of the country where temperatures are soaring.

Turkish Minister of Agriculture and Forestry Ibrahim Yumakli said on Wednesday that five forestry workers and five rescuers trying to tackle the blaze were killed when 24 firefighters became trapped in the wildfire earlier in the day.

Winds whipped up by the flames suddenly changed direction, and the fire engulfed the group of firefighters, who were swiftly transported to hospital, where 10 of them died.

Fourteen others are still receiving medical treatment, the minister said.

'Unfortunately, we have lost five forest workers and five [rescuers],' Yumakli told Turkish television broadcasters.

Turkish news website BirGun reported that the group were trapped by the fire and 'burned alive'.

Local lawmaker Nebi Hatipoglu wrote on X that there are 'no words to describe our grief'.

Flames and smoke rise from a house in Selcik village after a forest fire in the Bilecik area of Turkiye on July 23, 2025 [Sergen Sezgin/Anadolu]

Turkiye has been sweltering since Sunday under high temperatures and strong winds that have fanned wildfires between Istanbul and the capital, Ankara, with the spreading blazes threatening homes and forcing the evacuation of several villages.

Minister Yumakli said extreme heat and volatile wind conditions were also expected on Thursday.

'Starting tomorrow, we are facing extraordinary temperatures and extreme wind shifts. Once again, I call on all 86 million citizens to be vigilant and exercise extra caution,' he said.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan praised the victims who fought 'to protect our forests at cost of their lives'.

'I pray for God's mercy on our brothers and sisters who fought at the cost of their lives to protect our forests, and I offer my condolences to their families and our nation,' Erdogan said in a message posted on social media.

Two prosecutors have been assigned to investigate the incident, the country's justice minister said.

The deaths on Wednesday bring the number of deaths in wildfires so far in the country to 13 this year.

An elderly man and two forestry workers were killed in a wildfire that raged near the town of Odemis, in the Izmir province, earlier this month.

An aircraft drops water over a forest fire in the Kayapinar neighbourhood of the Yunusemre district in the Manisa area of Turkiye on Wednesday [Berkan Cetin/Anadolu]

urn:contentItem:6FS1-D3G3-RRW2-R2RD-00000-00New Physics Study Results from Zhejiang University of Science and Technology Described (An Improved Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Forest Fire Detection Model Based on YOLOv8)2025-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisPHYSICSNew Physics Study Results from Zhejiang University of Science and Technology Described (An Improved Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Forest Fire Detection Model Based on YOLOv8)


2025 MAY 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- New study results on physics have been published. According to news reporting from Hangzhou, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires have a great destructive impact on the Earth's ecosystem; therefore, the top priority of current research is how to accurately and quickly monitor forest fires. Taking into account efficiency and cost-effectiveness, deep-learning-driven UAV remote sensing fire detection algorithms have emerged as a favored research trend and have seen extensive application."


Funders for this research include The National Natural Science Foundation of China; Industry-university-research Innovation Fund of Chinese Colleges.
The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Zhejiang University of Science and Technology: "However, in the process of drone monitoring, fires often appear very small and are easily obstructed by trees, which greatly limits the amount of effective information that algorithms can extract. Meanwhile, considering the limitations of unmanned aerial vehicles, the algorithm model also needs to have lightweight characteristics. To address challenges such as the small targets, occlusions, and image blurriness in UAV-captured wildfire images, this paper proposes an improved UAV forest fire detection model based on YOLOv8. Firstly, we incorporate SPDConv modules, enhancing the YOLOv8 architecture and boosting its efficacy in dealing with minor objects and images with low resolution. Secondly, we introduce the C2f-PConv module, which effectively improves computational efficiency by reducing redundant calculations and memory access. Thirdly, the model boosts classification precision through the integration of a Mixed Local Channel Attention (MLCA) strategy preceding the three detection outputs. Finally, the W-IoU loss function is utilized, which adaptively modifies the weights for different target boxes within the loss computation, to efficiently address the difficulties associated with detecting small targets. The experimental results showed that the accuracy of our model increased by 2.17%, the recall increased by 5.5%, and the mAP@0.5 increased by 1.9%."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "In addition, the number of parameters decreased by 43.8%, with only 5.96M parameters, while the model size and GFlops decreased by 43.3% and 36.7%, respectively. Our model not only reduces the number of parameters and computational complexity, but also exhibits superior accuracy and effectiveness in UAV fire image recognition tasks, thereby offering a robust and reliable solution for UAV fire monitoring."
For more information on this research see: An Improved Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Forest Fire Detection Model Based on YOLOv8. Fire, 2025,8(4):138. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8040138.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Bensheng Yun, School of Science, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou 310023, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Xiaohan Xu, Jie Zeng, Zhenyu Lin, Jing He, Qiaoling Dai.

urn:contentItem:6FB3-1B43-RVNR-632T-00000-00Reports from Ferdowsi University of Mashhad Provide New Insights into Climate Change (Assessing Hyrcanian Forest Fire Vulnerability: Socioeconomic and Environmental Perspectives)2025-03-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEReports from Ferdowsi University of Mashhad Provide New Insights into Climate Change (Assessing Hyrcanian Forest Fire Vulnerability: Socioeconomic and Environmental Perspectives)


2025 MAR 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- New research on Climate Change is the subject of a report. According to news reporting out of Mashhad, Iran, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "The increasing frequency and intensity of forest fires, driven by climate change and human activities, pose a significant threat to vital forest ecosystems, particularly where fire is not a natural element in the regeneration cycle. This study aims to identify the indicators influencing forest fire vulnerability and compare maps of forest fire susceptibility that are based on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change tripartite model, with a focus on the vulnerable Hyrcanian forest region in Golestan Province, northern Iran, where forest fires have caused considerable economic losses."


Financial support for this research came from University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences Vienna (BOKU).
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, "On the basis of expert opinions and a literature review, we used geographic information systems, remote sensing and machine learning techniques to select and weigh 30 biophysical, environmental and socioeconomic indicators that affect forest fire vulnerability in the study area. These indicators were rigorously normalized, weighted and amalgamated into a comprehensive forest fire vulnerability index to analyze forest exposure, sensitivity and adaptive capacity. We thus identified and mapped areas with very high forest fire exposure, high sensitivity and low adaptive capacity for urgent targeted intervention and strategic planning to mitigate the impacts of forest fires. The results also revealed a set of critical indicators that contribute more significantly to forest fire vulnerability (e.g., precipitation, elevation and factors related to biodiversity, human activity and economic reliance on forest resources)."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our results provide insights that can inform policy-making, community engagement and environmental management strategies to mitigate the vulnerabilities associated with forest fires in the Hyrcanian forest."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Assessing Hyrcanian Forest Fire Vulnerability: Socioeconomic and Environmental Perspectives. Journal of Forestry Research, 2025;36(1). Journal of Forestry Research can be contacted at: Northeast Forestry Univ, No 26 Hexing Rd, Xiangfang District, Harbin, 150040, Peoples R China. (Springer - www.springer.com; Journal of Forestry Research - www.springerlink.com/content/1007-662x/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Mahmoud Sabouhi Sabouni, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Faculty of Agriculture, Dept. of Agricultural Economics, Mashhad, Iran. Additional authors for this research include Elnaz Nejatiyanpour, Mahmoud Daneshvar Kakhki, Omid Ghorbanzadeh, Josef Strobl, Rasoul Yousefpour, Hamid Amirnejad and Khalil Gholamnia.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11676-025-01832-z. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GM1-4503-RT8J-J46J-00000-00Wildfire emissions across EU countries hit record high2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWildfire emissions across EU countries hit record highJONATHAN POWELL in London

Climate-warming emissions from wildfires across the European Union have reached record high this year, with more than 1 million hectares burned since January, an area larger than Cyprus.

Fires across the continent, especially in Spain and Portugal, have emitted about 38 million tons of carbon dioxide so far, surpassing Sweden's annual CO2 output, according to the European Forest Fire Information System, or EFFIS.

That total is more than double the 20-year average for this point in the year, EFFIS reported.

Spain and Portugal are enduring their worst wildfire season on record, with August blazes killing at least seven people, displacing thousands, and destroying homes and crops as the peninsula baked under heat waves.

Mark Parrington, a senior scientist at the EU's Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service, told The Guardian newspaper the fires sweeping the Iberian Peninsula this month have been "exceptional".

"The large quantities of smoke — and especially PM2.5 — released into the atmosphere have resulted in severely degraded air quality locally, and further afield across the Iberian Peninsula and parts of France."

He added that in Spain, fire-related emissions this year are already about four times the average annual total.

A total of 1.028 million hectares have burned across the EU so far this year, the highest year-to-date since records began in 2006, and already exceeding the previous full-year high of about 998,000 hectares in 2017.

Spain and Portugal account for about two-thirds of the EU's burned area, according to a Reuters analysis of EFFIS data, which show a spike in fires between Aug 5 and Aug 19, coinciding with a 16-day heat wave in the Iberian Peninsula.

Cristina Santin Nuno, a fire scientist with Spain's National Research Council, was quoted by The Guardian as saying the "perfect conditions "for large, dangerous wildfires are occurring more often due to climate change and land-use practices. "It is sad and scary — my home region is burning right now — but not surprising, really," she said.

She added that a "catastrophic "wildfire season is unlikely every year, but the likelihood of record-breaking seasons is increasing annually.

It is "highly probable" the record in 2025 will be broken again within a few years, she said. "This is a new reality. And the sooner we realize it, and take action to be more resilient to these types of wildfires, the better."

jonathan@mail.chinadailyuk.com

 

Link to Image

People watch a wildfire burning in Castrillo de Cabrera, northwestern Spain, on Aug 16. CESAR MANSO/AFP

He added that in Spain, fire-related emissions this year are already about four times the average annual total.

A total of 1.028 million hectares have burned across the EU so far this year, the highest year-to-date since records began in 2006, and already exceeding the previous full-year high of about 998,000 hectares in 2017.

Spain and Portugal account for about two-thirds of the EU's burned area, according to a Reuters analysis of EFFIS data, which show a spike in fires between Aug 5 and Aug 19, coinciding with a 16-day heat wave in the Iberian Peninsula.

Cristina Santin Nuno, a fire scientist with Spain's National Research Council, was quoted by The Guardian as saying the "perfect conditions "for large, dangerous wildfires are occurring more often due to climate change and land-use practices. "It is sad and scary — my home region is burning right now — but not surprising, really," she said.

She added that a "catastrophic "wildfire season is unlikely every year, but the likelihood of record-breaking seasons is increasing annually.

It is "highly probable" the record in 2025 will be broken again within a few years, she said. "This is a new reality. And the sooner we realize it, and take action to be more resilient to these types of wildfires, the better."

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G1B3-RS1P-J4TS-00000-00Juanma Moreno's PP will promote a law to facilitate the sentencing of arsonists2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisJuanma Moreno's PP will promote a law to facilitate the sentencing of arsonists


The PP of Andalusia will propose a law to the Government presided by Pedro Sanchez to facilitate the prosecution and conviction of arsonists who have carried out a forest fire in bad faith, most of the fires that have ravaged the country in recent weeks being man-made. This rule would support the work of investigators and make it easier for arsonists to be convicted with "definitive indications and evidence", as currently strong indications are not enough to imprison the executor of a fire.


This idea was already endorsed by the Andalusian president, Juanma Moreno, who last week called for tougher penalties for those who cause fires considering that the current Penal Code is "innocuous" for arsonists, whom he described as "murderers" of nature. A request made by the leader of the Andalusian popular after it was revealed that the evidence pointed to the Tarifa fire had been intentionally set.
In this sense, the Andalusian Popular will promote a rule to remove obstacles to the prosecution of the perpetrators of the fires through its government in the Board. Thus, they intend to toughen the penalties for those who cause the fires, as well as to support the work of investigators by offering them more means to do their work.
The Councilor of the Presidency of the Andalusian Government and coordinator of the Interior of the PP in Genoa, Antonio Sanz, has also stressed that his formation is studying measures to change the rules. Thus, Justice will be able to act calmly -currentlyif there is no evidence the arsonist is free within hours-when there is a "regrettable circumstance, of bad intention" that is to say, that everything indicates that the fire has been caused "in bad faith" with the aim of harming the environment.
In this context, Sanz stressed the importance of citizen collaboration to identify the perpetrators of fires, which, he said referring to the fatalities that have occurred this month due to fire, can cause both material and personal damage irreparable.

urn:contentItem:6GF4-Y533-RS54-B2HR-00000-00August starts with air quality alerts in NH2025-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSAugust starts with air quality alerts in NHElijah de CastroThe Keene Sentinel, N.H.

Smoke from wildfires in Canada is bringing unsafe levels of fine particle pollution to the Monadnock Region for the second time this summer.

The N.H. Department of Environmental Services declared an air quality action day for Tuesday, citing pollution from high concentrations of fine particles from the wildfires.

Air quality alerts have been issued throughout the Northeast and Midwest. The pollution is expected to continue over the following days.

According to DES' live air quality monitor, Cheshire and Hillsborough counties were listed as "unhealthy for sensitive people," as of late morning Tuesday. These groups include people with asthma, people who are elderly and children.

"People with asthma and other existing lung diseases may not be able to breathe as deeply or vigorously as normal and may experience symptoms such as coughing and shortness of breath," the department said in a news release.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, which monitors wildfires throughout the country, said there were 745 active wildfires as of midday Tuesday, most of which were considered out of control.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-8V53-RW0Y-K10R-00000-00Lightning-induced wildfires to increase with climate change2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisLightning-induced wildfires to increase with climate changeNew Delhi

New Delhi, Sept. 9 -- Summary

Climate change will increase lightning-induced wildfires, which already account for nearly half of all wildfires in Canada.

As vegetation and lightning strikes rise, more extensive burnt areas are expected.

This can overwhelm fire management efforts.

The trend is mirrored in the US and Europe, where lightning also triggers significant wildfires.

Lightning-induced fires contribute to almost half of all the wildfires and over 90 per cent of the burnt area in Canadian forests, scientists have found.

The effects of climate change, they warned in a study conducted from 2000 through 2020, will result in increased frequency of such instances, as vegetation cover and lightning strikes are expected to rise.

In 2024, Environment and Climate Change Canada's global atmospheric model estimated that increases in lightning in northern mid-latitudes will result in greater area burnt by the end of the century, according to the study published in May 2025.

Lightning-induced wildfires to increase with climate change

Each year, an average of 1.96 million hectares of land in Canada is burnt by forest fires. The study said that between 1959 and 2015, lightning played a role in about 50 per cent of wildfires, while the other half was caused due to anthropogenic factors.

Fires ignited by lightning led to a more extensive burnt area because they happened in isolated regions, unlike those caused due to anthropogenic triggers, because they were closer to human habitations and could be contained quickly.

Moreover, the lightning-induced forest fires were spatially distributed in clusters, overwhelming the fire management agencies to address them in multiple and remote areas.

Another study published in August pointed out cloud-to-ground (CG) lightning is a major source of summer wildfire ignition in the western United States (WUS). These fires are responsible for wiping out over two-thirds of the total burnt area in the region.

"Smoke from these fires has detrimental effects on air quality and public health and has partially reversed air quality improvements stemming from the Clean Air Act. As the climate continues to warm in the WUS, the risk of wildfires - including those sparked by lightning - is projected to grow due to drier vegetation," the study said.

Lightning-induced wildfires to increase with climate change

It was also observed that climate change has led to alterations in surface heating, moisture fluctuations and circulation changes, which contribute to cloud-to-ground lightning occurrences and precipitation. This increases the risk of flash floods and slope failures due to heavy rain-producing thunderstorms, especially impacting recently burnt areas.

The risks in these areas may not necessarily be from lightning-induced wildfire but rather hydrologic hazards.

The researchers factored in Fine Fuel Moisture Code, Duff Moisture Code and Drought Code from the Canadian Forest Fire Weather Index (FWI) System to understand and estimate fire ignition possibility due to lightning.

The study predicted coincidence in cloud-to-ground lightning days with FWI by 2031 and 2060, particularly in the interior northwestern US.

Lightning-induced wildfires to increase with climate change

Apart from the US, wildfires have wiped out over 1 million hectares of forests in Europe this year, releasing volumes of carbon dioxide equivalent to the annual emissions of Sweden or Portugal.

Lightning was found to be responsible for triggering wildfires in Portugal and Spain.

urn:contentItem:6FHD-8WM3-RSPP-72X8-00000-00New Machine Learning Study Findings Reported from Kyungpook National University (Assessment of forest fire vulnerability prediction in Indonesia: Seasonal variability analysis using machine learning techniques)2025-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGNew Machine Learning Study Findings Reported from Kyungpook National University (Assessment of forest fire vulnerability prediction in Indonesia: Seasonal variability analysis using machine learning techniques)


2025 APR 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Research findings on artificial intelligence are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from Sangju, South Korea, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires significantly threaten Indonesia's tropical forests, driven by complex interactions between human activity, environmental conditions and climate variability. This research aims to identify and analyze the factors influencing forest fires in Kalimantan, Sumatra, and Papua during the rainy, dry and all-season conditions using machine learning techniques and create vulnerability prediction maps and categorize risk zones."


Funders for this research include Korea Ministry of Education; Korea Ministry of Science And Ict.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Kyungpook National University: "Eight years (2015-2022) of forest fire data were combined with 15 forest fire susceptible factors that consider of human, environmental, meteorological, and land use/land cover conditioning factors. Random forest (RF) and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGB) machine learning models were used to train and validate the dataset through hyperparameter tuning and 10-fold cross-validation for accuracy assessment. The XGB model was selected as the best performer based on accuracy, recall, and F1-score and was used to generate probability values. The evaluation showed that the accuracies and AUC values for the nine models were greater than 0.7, with AUC values ranging from 0.71 to 0.95, indicating good performance. Papua had the highest accuracy, with 90.5%, 91.6%, and 92.5% for all, rainy, and dry seasons, respectively. Population density, elevation, precipitation, soil moisture, NDMI, NDVI, distance from roads and settlements, land surface temperature and peatlands are the key contributing factors of forest fire occurrences. Vulnerability maps categorized into five risk zones, identifying high-risk areas that aligned with observed fire occurrences."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This research highlighted the diverse characteristics of factors that determine forest fires and examined their impact on fire occurrences. The findings provide actionable insights for targeted fire management strategies, though future research should incorporate additional variables to improve predictive accuracy and address long-term environmental changes."
For more information on this research see: Assessment of forest fire vulnerability prediction in Indonesia: Seasonal variability analysis using machine learning techniques. International Journal of Applied Earth Observations and Geoinformation, 2025,138():104435. The publisher for International Journal of Applied Earth Observations and Geoinformation is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jag.2025.104435.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Wulan Salle Karurung, Department of Convergence and Fusion System Engineering, Kyungpook National University, Sangju, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include Kangjae Lee, Wonhee Lee.
Keywords for this news article include: Kyungpook National University, Sangju, South Korea, , Asia, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Indonesia, Machine Learning.

urn:contentItem:6GK8-1YH3-RV8H-B0SS-00000-00Wildfires In NJ? How We're Keeping Our Communities Safe And Our Energy Systems Reliable At PSEG.2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWildfires In NJ? How We're Keeping Our Communities Safe And Our Energy Systems Reliable At PSEG.

Link to Image

Link to Story

Originally published on PSEG ENERGIZE! We're working hard to help you and your community be ready while maintaining the reliability of our energy system-even in the event of possible wildfires.


Here's how we're working year-round:
We're watching the skies.
We work with state and national weather agencies to monitor heat, humidity and wind conditions. FEMA Red Flag Warnings let us know when to shift into high gear.
What this means for you: We can be prepared to adjust field operations when wildfire risk levels rise and work with emergency partners from NJ Forest Fire Service and local fire fighters to local and regional OEM.
Read more about the National Weather Service's fire warnings and watches .
We're trimming trees and vegetation.
We're always out and about trimming trees near power lines to help avoid outages - a key component of our reliability strategy.
We're in sync with first responders.
We don't wait for a crisis to connect. We participate in training exercises with local fire departments and emergency management teams if and when requested.
What this means for you: If a wildfire does happen, the right people are ready to take action - fast.
We're practicing like its game day.
"Wildfire preparedness isn't seasonal anymore," said Jorge Moya, PSE&G senior director of Emergency Preparedness."It's something we prepare for all year."
That means more drills, continuously improving plans and smoother coordination with first responders - all to protect your community.
Your safety is our priority - every season.
Whether it's the middle of summer or a fall day, we're always working to stay ahead of wildfires because safety is our number one priority - for us, and for the people we serve.
Stay connected and informed at pseg/WildfireSafety.
Emergency Preparedness Tools Available
The PSEG Foundation and Sesame Workshop have partnered to create bilingual (English and Spanish), multiple media programs that help families prepare for, and respond to, emergencies and provide tools so that children can build the skills they need to become resilient. Find out more here .

PSEG

August 25th, 2025 ( 3BL Blogs - Delivered by Newstex )

Originally published on PSEG ENERGIZE!

We're working hard to help you and your community be ready while maintaining the reliability of our energy system-even in the event of possible wildfires.

Here's how we're working year-round:

We're watching the skies.

We work with state and national weather agencies to monitor heat, humidity and wind conditions. FEMA Red Flag Warnings let us know when to shift into high gear.

What this means for you: We can be prepared to adjust field operations when wildfire risk levels rise and work with emergency partners from NJ Forest Fire Service and local fire fighters to local and regional OEM.

Read more about the National Weather Service's fire warnings and watches.

We're trimming trees and vegetation.

We're always out and about trimming trees near power lines to help avoid outages - a key component of our reliability strategy.

We're in sync with first responders.

We don't wait for a crisis to connect. We participate in training exercises with local fire departments and emergency management teams if and when requested.

What this means for you: If a wildfire does happen, the right people are ready to take action - fast.

We're practicing like its game day.

'Wildfire preparedness isn't seasonal anymore,' said Jorge Moya, PSE&G senior director of Emergency Preparedness. 'It's something we prepare for all year.'

That means more drills, continuously improving plans and smoother coordination with first responders - all to protect your community.

Your safety is our priority - every season.

Whether it's the middle of summer or a fall day, we're always working to stay ahead of wildfires because safety is our number one priority - for us, and for the people we serve.

Stay connected and informed at pseg.com/WildfireSafety.

Emergency Preparedness Tools Available

The PSEG Foundationand Sesame Workshop have partnered to create bilingual (English and Spanish), multiple media programs that help families prepare for, and respond to, emergencies and provide tools so that children can build the skills they need to become resilient. Find out more here.

Link to the original story.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DG53-RRXD-504J-00000-00Wave of wildfires threatens thousands of homes on the U.S. West Coast2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWave of wildfires threatens thousands of homes on the U.S. West Coast

CARBALLEDA DE AVIA (OURENSE), 08/17/2025.- A forest ranger works in extinguishing the forest fire in Carballeda de Avia (Ourense) this Sunday. The wave of fires that affects the northwest of Spain does not give truce this Sunday. After a week of fires that have caused three deaths, thousands of hectares burned and thousands of people displaced by the flames, the country is devastated. In the region of Galicia 50,000 hectares have already burned and in the region of Castilla y León 3,500 people remained outside their homes. EFE/ Brais Lorenzo
A wave of fires on the west coast of the United States threatens to destroy thousands of homes in one of the main wine regions located between northern California and Oregon, while emergency teams fight the flames in the midst of an intense heat wave.


The Pickett Fire, considered the most severe so far, is just 13% contained and has scorched 6,800 acres (2,700 hectares). The situation has placed thousands of homes in Napa County under evacuation orders, according to the latest report from the California Fire Department (CalFire).
The Fires
Although fire activity managed to slow slightly over the weekend, CalFire warned that the flames "continue to be fueled by brush, grasses and dead trees, contributing to their increased intensity."
In response to the emergency, the California government deployed personnel in 12 counties, including the Los Angeles metropolitan area, as well as Kern, San Diego, Santa Barbara, Ventura, Sierra Nevada, Plumas, Placer, Calaveras and Trinity, among others, to reinforce firefighting efforts.
In Oregon, the Flat Fire is threatening more than 4,000 homes as it rages out of control. The state Fire Department reported that "the Flat Fire is estimated to encompass 21,971 acres (8,500 hectares) with 0 percent containment. The fire is burning approximately two miles northeast of the city of Sisters" in the center of the state.
The situation revives fears of a repeat of the devastating fires that earlier this year affected Los Angeles County, considered among the most serious in the country's recent history.
That wave of fires, which began on January 7 and took more than three weeks to extinguish, left 31 people dead, 150,000 evacuated, more than 16,000 structures destroyed and became one of the most costly natural disasters in the United States.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DFT3-RRR5-S1P8-00000-00The PP called for a deployment of aerial resources against fires that is double that of the EU.2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisThe PP called for a deployment of aerial resources against fires that is double that of the EU.


The request for air resources that the communities of Castilla y León, Extremadura and Galicia, all three of them PP, made on August 15 to the Government after Alberto Núñez Feijóo's demand to deploy the Army beyond the EMU was so exceptional and sudden that it doubled the number of planes and helicopters for firefighting of the European Mechanism for Civil Protection. Brussels has 26 aircraft for the 2025 fire campaign for the whole of Europe. The unprecedented call for resources ended up unleashing the crossfire between the PP and the PSOE. The Popular Party reproached that same weekend that the resources had not arrived. The general director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, replied that the PP presidents had asked for "impossible" and Elías Bendodo called her a "pyromaniac".


The Executive of Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, who on the 14th assured that the Junta had "sufficient means", went on to request a day later, within a very long list, 20 personnel transport helicopters and 10 water bomber helicopters. The Junta, presided by María Guardiola, in turn requested 10 amphibious planes and 10 light helicopters. The Xunta, led by Alfonso Rueda, generically requested "all the fixed-wing aircraft or helicopters available to the central government".
To get an idea of the dimension of the resources demanded by the regional presidents of the PP - 40 helicopters and 10 aircraft - the Community Protection System, created in 2001 to strengthen cooperation between EU countries and improve prevention and response to such natural disasters, this year has 22 aircraft (Spain provides two of the 14 Canadair CL-415 aircraft to a fleet that completes 6 Fireboss aircraft and two Air Tractor) and four helicopters, according to data from the European Commission. In addition, Member States can make voluntary, ad hoc offers for specific emergencies in other countries. This is what has happened with two Chinook helicopters that the Netherlands offered to Spain in the wave of fires that have devastated more than 400,000 hectares in 15 days, concentrated in the provinces of Ourense, Zamora, León and Cáceres, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
On August 15, Mañueco also requested in writing to the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande-Marlaska, 1,000 soldiers, 25 bulldozers "with the most expert machinists possible in the bush", 15 mother vehicles and 15 advanced command posts. "In addition to these resources, it is necessary that the Government of Spain requests the arrival of new means within the European Civil Protection Mechanism," added the president of Castilla y León in his letter, which was sent at 22.52.
Half an hour before, the Extremadura Minister of the Presidency, Abel Bautista, "having knowledge of the activation of the European aid" - a decision that the Government formalized in the early morning of August 12, when it declared the pre-emergency - sent a request for troops to help in the emergency, moved a request for troops to fight the simultaneous fires that the community suffered "since August 11" and that at that time had burned about 5,000 hectares in Llerena (Badajoz) and 4,800 in Jarilla (Cáceres), which would end up becoming the most serious in the history of the region after burning more than 17,000 hectares. In his letter, the Minister "urges to request new means to Brussels, with the activation of the following means for the autonomous community of Extremadura: 100 light trucks equipped with forest firefighters, 10 amphibious planes and 10 light helicopters". Later, in another e-mail, he insisted on the "deployment of operative means, heavy machinery and aerial means of the Army in Extremadura to help in the extinction tasks". And he reiterated: "The mobilization of means and resources arriving from Europe is necessary".
Two days later, on August 17, Feijóo accused the Government of not having appealed to Brussels for help. "We have been asking for days to activate EU aid for more air resources and the deployment of Army troops and machinery. The Government has to stop always being late. I ask Sanchez not to let more time pass and the means arrive now," he posted on his account in X despite the fact that it was not so. As an example, on the 16th, two Italian air tankers provided by Brussels landed at the Matacán air base (Salamanca) to fight the fires. Earlier, on the 14th, another two Canadair planes supplied by France and with a capacity of more than 5,500 liters each arrived in Galicia.
The aerial resources deployed by Brussels in Spain in August were also four helicopters (two Czech and two Slovak Black Hawks). As for the ground teams, three teams of firefighters on foot have been provided by Finland, Romania and Greece - the EU has eight such teams, of which Spain contributes with two - and three teams of firefighters with vehicles (two from France and one from Germany) of the 17 existing ones. Since July, the European system has participated in 16 fire emergencies concentrated in the Iberian Peninsula and the Balkans.
Dolors Montserrat, secretary general of the European People's Party, returned this Sunday to hold the government responsible for the severity of the fires of the last two weeks. "In 2021, the Government of Sanchez asked for 401 million of the Next Generation for forest management and fire prevention and there are still 320 million to invest," she said. The Ministry of Ecological Transition claims that the Government has transferred 253 million to the autonomous communities for investment in prevention and extinction. Sara Aagesen's department assures that it has allocated another 149 million to the "modernization of all the operational bases" of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF) and the "modernization of the avionics of the Ministry's aerial firefighting operations".

urn:contentItem:6GS9-PS63-RS7W-K2W4-00000-00Mataró pushes for the closure of an irregular camping site where hundreds of vulnerable families live2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisMataró pushes for the closure of an irregular camping site where hundreds of vulnerable families live


The City Council of Mataró (Maresme) has initiated legal proceedings to evict an illegal campsite installed on rural land in the forest area north of the city. They demand the closure of the activities once the company promoting the plots was urged to voluntarily evict the people living in the enclosure of about 12 hectares. According to the Consistory that urges the forced execution of the closure of the illegal campsite, it is rustic land.


What began about three years ago as a business venture of two brothers to promote a farm, was becoming a parceled space that have been renting to vulnerable people. "Evicted people and vulnerable families started coming to us to ask for help and we let them settle in caravans, tents and huts," explains Bilal El Harrak, one of the promoters. Now more than 100 families live there, all of them highly socially vulnerable, including political refugees from South American countries and 50 socially deprived minors.
"We have tried to protect all these vulnerable people" justifies El Harrak, although he acknowledges that they also get an economic return. "There are families who, because of their critical situation, do not pay and others pay the monthly rent according to their capacities". In exchange, they get well water and electricity supplied by several generators, "just enough for a TV and a few light bulbs". Each family has been building a home on the plots, "some with motor homes, others with prefabricated modules and several with wood".
In the end, despite pressure from the authorities, "we have been building a community that helps each other" and gives shelter to families who have been left out of the social circuits. Some are evicted from their homes, others were living in vehicles and others were wandering the streets.
El Harrak regrets that the City Council does not attend to the families sheltered in the campsite. Mari, an Andalusian with four children who needs regular dialysis, and a Venezuelan family with disabled children who had to flee their country, have their home there. Some Spaniards are at risk of exclusion, like the owner of a nearby farm whose wealthy owners left him abandoned to his fate, and others whom Sareb "forced us to leave the apartment".
All this nonsense began 25 years ago when a famous real estate developer acquired the land "thinking they could build luxury homes, but the mayor changed and the land was never requalified". So they decided to rent all the hectares for farming, which did not bear fruit. "We went bankrupt with the watermelon business," Bilal acknowledges.
More than fifty minors at risk of social exclusion live in the area.
The City Council considers that it is a flagrant case of shantyism which they oppose head-on and which has been litigated for years with urban discipline proceedings and sanctions. The case has been taken to the Environmental Prosecutor's Office and the Mossos d'Esquadra. The land is located in a periurban area of special natural protection, next to the road to Mata and that, according to municipal technicians, "has a high potential fire risk" especially for its continuity with the Parc Natural del Montnegre i Corredor. "The existence of people living continuously in the campsite increases very significantly the risk of forest fire" they certify.
The families affected by the eviction have initiated protest actions, such as the collection of signatures on digital platforms supported by social entities such as the Sindicat de l'Habitatge, which makes explicit the vulnerability of the people staying at the campsite. They warn that "this new shantyism may end up being a trend" if "rentier" options continue to be defended and evictions are carried out instead of "attacking the root of the problem".
On the other hand, the neighbors of nearby urbanizations, such as Can Quirze, who are also clamoring against shantyism and the supposed danger it entails, support the municipal decision, as well as the farmers of the agricultural area of Les Cinc Sènies, who show their concern because more and more agricultural spaces are being "scratched".
