urn:contentItem:6GPD-0413-RTP6-Y4TW-00000-00France's Prime Minister François Bayroun to resign Tuesday after losing confidence motion2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisFrance's Prime Minister François Bayroun to resign Tuesday after losing confidence motion


The French Prime Minister, François Bayrou, lost this Monday the motion of confidence to which he was submitted in the Parliament, the fourth Prime Minister since January 2024, who starred in the announced chronicle of his fall and that of his government.


The French National Assembly voted by 364 votes to 194 to remove him from office and overthrow his minority government, failing to pass the vote on a motion of confidence called by the same. Another 25 deputies abstained.
YOU MAY BE INTERESTED: EU accuses France of thwarting Gaza cease-fire by recognizing Palestine as a state
The entire opposition, the extreme right and all left-wing groups, voted against in that motion that Bayrou decided to call to validate his gloomy diagnosis on French public finances and on the need for a 44 billion euro cut in the deficit in the budgets for 2026.
Bayrou will tender his resignation on Tuesday, according to his entourage. He is the fourth prime minister to parade through the Elysee since the May 2022 start of Macron's second term, after Elisabeth Borne (until January 2024), Gabriel Attal (until September 2024) and Michel Barnier (until December 2024).
POLITICAL INSTABILITY IN FRANCE
Since the failed early elections of 2024, France has been experiencing a deep political instability without stable parliamentary majorities, in a context of high public debt reaching about 114% of GDP.
The French presidency later reported that Macron will appoint a new prime minister "in the coming days."
Macron "takes note of the result of the deputies' vote" and "will appoint a new prime minister in the coming days," the French presidency said in a statement, minutes after Bayrou's fall in a confidence motion.
YOU MAY BE INTERESTED: Forest fire in France, one of the biggest in its history
The far-right leader, Marine Le Pen, estimated that Macron has a moral "obligation" to call early legislative elections.
Le Pen would not be able to run in the elections as she is sentenced to a disqualification sentence for embezzlement of European public funds. Her trial on appeal will take place between January 13 and February 12.
According to the polls, these elections would again leave an Assembly divided into three blocs left, center-right and far-right and without stable majorities, although with a rise of Le Pen's party and a fall of the ruling party.
Macron advocated last week to look to his left and try to attract the socialist opposition to the current government, formed by his centrist alliance and the conservative party The Republicans (LR).
"We are ready, let him come and get us," assured this Monday the Socialist deputy, Boris Vallaud, who specified, however, that it is now up to the "left", winner of the 2024 legislative elections, to form a government.
YOU MAY BE INTERESTED: Devastation continues in France due to worst wildfire in decades
The fall of a new government could lead Macron to resign. The president has already ruled out this scenario, which 64% of French people want, according to a recent Odoxa-Backbone poll, and which the radical left is already calling for.
"Bayrou fell (...) Macron is now on the front line in front of the people. He too must go," wrote leftist leader Jean-Luc Mélenchon on the social network X.

urn:contentItem:6F8K-D7S3-RT5J-24ST-00000-00University of Freiburg Reports Findings in Climate Change (Mapping the probability of forest fire hazard across the European Alps under climate change scenarios)2025-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEUniversity of Freiburg Reports Findings in Climate Change (Mapping the probability of forest fire hazard across the European Alps under climate change scenarios)


2025 MAR 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- New research on Climate Change is the subject of a report. According to news reporting out of Freiburg, Germany, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires are increasing in frequency and intensity worldwide due to the anthropogenic climate change, threatening people's lives and causing huge economic and environmental damages. Recent forest fire events suggest that forest fires are also an urgent issue in the European Alps, but studies assessing the forest fire hazard under future climate scenarios are still rare."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the University of Freiburg, "Thus, this study aims to analyse the impacts of climate change on the probability of forest fire hazard across the European Alps and surrounding areas. In specific, we (1) explain the current forest fire hazard based on a set of environmental and anthropogenic parameters, and (2) map the forest fire hazard under current and future conditions across the study area using geographically weighted regression. Our results suggest that the fire hazard mainly depends on the frequency of lightning strikes, the annual mean temperature, and the precipitation seasonality. Overall, our results indicate a future increase in forest fire hazard, which is already significant under the SSP126 (+15.5%), while highest increases occur under the SSP370 (30.6%) and the SSP585 (35.4%). However, while the impacts are less pronounced in already fire-prone regions in the southwestern regions in France, the probability of forest fire hazard will greatly increase in the Northern and Eastern regions. Our findings emphasize the urgent need to address these climate-related challenges by decision-making and management through fire-smart forest management."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Nevertheless, further efforts are needed to overcome current limitations related to data availability and uncertainties in future scenarios."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Mapping the probability of forest fire hazard across the European Alps under climate change scenarios. Journal of Environmental Management, 2025;377:124600. Journal of Environmental Management can be contacted at: Academic Press Ltd- Elsevier Science Ltd, 24-28 Oval Rd, London NW1 7DX, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Journal of Environmental Management - www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-environmental-management/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Kilian Gerberding, Faculty of Environment and Natural Resources, University of Freiburg, Tennenbacher Str. 4, Freiburg, 79106, Germany.
Publisher contact information for the Journal of Environmental Management is: Academic Press Ltd- Elsevier Science Ltd, 24-28 Oval Rd, London NW1 7DX, England.

urn:contentItem:6GNM-1S83-S0CC-B019-00000-00Private forests are at higher risk of severe wildfires: What this means for carbon storage2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITYPrivate forests are at higher risk of severe wildfires: What this means for carbon storageTeodora Lyubomirova, Teodora

Compared to public forests, industrially-managed forests are nearly 1.5 times more likely to fuel megafires, according to a new study published in Global Change Biology.

Wildfires can impact global efforts to keep carbon locked into trees, wood and forest soils: a practice known as carbon sequestration.

Wildfires lead to the re-release of large amounts of carbon from timber and soils back into the atmosphere; impact forests’ ability to regenerate and thus, their role as natural carbon sinks, and may also hamper carbon offsetting efforts if the fire-ravaged forests are managed for carbon credits.

The latter should be a warning for companies who invest or consider investing in industrial tree planting or carbon credit schemes as part of their sustainability strategies by considering the risks of forest fires on their investment.

So why do private forests fare worse than public ones?

Weather and forest density conspire to bring a higher fire risk

A study led by Jacob I. Levine found that industrially-managed forests are typically of higher density, have similar types of trees which are also of a similar age. This homogenous structure makes private forests more susceptible to wildfires than publicly-managed ones, with the scholars estimating that high-severity fires were 1.45 times more likely to take place at industrially-managed land than public.

But weather also plays a part in the risk equation.

High-severity fire risk increases under extreme weather conditions, particularly in hot and dry and when fuel moisture is low, according to the research. In hot weather, fire can spread crown-to-crown, making large trees a liability while diminishing the role of ‘fuel ladders’ such as vegetation that weaves onto the tree trunks from the ground up.

Importantly, even well-managed forests may experience high-severity fire if extreme weather is intense enough:

Ultimately, forest management holds the key to limiting fire risk in both private and public land: forests with reduced density and greater heterogeneity are at a lower risk of ever being felled by megafires, even in extreme weather conditions.

What forest fire risk means for business

These findings can be of critical importance for businesses investing in forest-based carbon credits, particularly in fire-prone regions such as California.

This is because high-severity fires kill over 95% of trees, impacting forest carbon integrity but also carbon permanence.

Businesses should therefore adjust their risk models to consider forest structure, ownership type, and regional weather and fire trends to figure out if they are making a smart investment; or whether a carbon credit scheme may be overvalued or vulnerable to reversal.

The study also highlights the importance of realtime monitoring of forest conditions and the need for buffer pools or insurance mechanisms to cover carbon losses from fire.

Source:

Extreme Weather Magnifies the Effects of Forest Structure on Wildfire, Driving Increased Severity in Industrial Forests

Jacob I. Levine, Brandon M. Collins, Michelle Coppoletta, Scott L. Stephens

First published: 20 August 2025

https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.70400

urn:contentItem:6GMX-CFG3-RWXH-M0D3-00000-00With N.S. brooks and streams drying up, some fish are struggling2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWith N.S. brooks and streams drying up, some fish are struggling

The drought in Nova Scotia is causing some brooks and streams to dry up, causing problems for some fish species, but the woods ban in parts of the province is making it difficult to understand the full scope of the problem.

In Cambridge, Kings County, the Rockford Brook usually connects to the Cornwallis River, but parts of the stream have dried up, leaving schools of trout and white suckers unable to reach their usual destinations. And in one deeper spot, water levels have dropped, turning the brook into an isolated pool of water.

Fen Boates-Bishop, a volunteer with the Jijuktu'kwejk Watershed Alliance, said this sometimes happens for a few days each summer, but the fish here have been isolated for over two months.

"There's a lack of oxygen, there can be a lack of food and competition for food and space in these pools, and that just leads to general stress for the fish and that could be harmful for them," he said.

And while he has seen this happen in other brooks that are outside wooded areas or on private properties, he can't know for sure how many tributaries in the watershed have been affected, because he can't access them without risking a fine of up to $25,000.

Kings County is one of the 11 counties where the woods ban remains in place.

Blistering temperatures earlier this summer meant water temperatures warmed to over 20 C, which was bad for the trout and white suckers' health, said Boates-Bishop.

But for some species, warmer waters are less problematic, said Boates-Bishop. He said invasive species like chain pickerel adapt more easily to warmer waters, giving them an advantage over native fish.

Commercial fisherman Darren Porter says eels can handle lower water levels well.

"Eels ... can breathe through their skin if they're damp and move up and down systems to find safer spots," he said.

While rain is needed to restore water levels, Porter encourages people to think about how they use water in their homes or their farms.

"If we're using the water, the fish don't have it," he said.

Rachel Walsh, aquatic program manager for Clean Annapolis River Project, said her group is quite concerned about Atlantic salmon.

"For adults returning from the ocean, drought creates barriers to migration," she wrote in an email. "Low water and dry stream beds can block their passage to spawning grounds. Even if they do reach spawning areas, stressful conditions can reduce reproductive success."

And while the group usually carries out projects to improve water flow and the habitability of spawning areas, that work has now stopped.

"However, with the current weather, woods ban and large forest fire in our region, we haven't been able to conduct any restoration work this summer," she said.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RH83-S7KW-C43D-00000-00The situation in León is "very favorable" after the fires in Anllares del Sil and Berlanga were reduced to zero severity.2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisThe situation in León is "very favorable" after the fires in Anllares del Sil and Berlanga were reduced to zero severity.


The situation in the province of León is "very favorable" at the end of the day this Friday since the improvement in the evolution of the fire of Fasgar-Colinas, which is in Potential Severity Index (IGR) 2 has allowed to lift the confinement of Igüeña and Colinas, while the fires of Yeres, Anllares and Garaño and Berlanga del Bierzo are stabilized and controlled.


This has moved the territorial delegate of the Board, Eduardo Diego, in statements to the media after participating in the meeting of CECOPI this afternoon, which has highlighted that at this time in the province only remains in Potential Severity Index (IGR) 2 fire Fasgar-Colinas, which remains at that level as a precaution.
Therefore, at the meeting that will take place this Saturday morning, it will be assessed if it is downgraded to severity 1 since "there is no threat to populations and the situation is very favorable as there is no flame".
For its part, the forest fire of Barniedo de la Reina remains at severity 1 as its perimeter is stabilized, although during the day this Friday there has been some reproduction that has been controlled. In this case, he pointed out that the works being carried out are of consolidation and there is no threat to populations.
Regarding the fire of La Baña, the representative of the regional executive has highlighted that the evolution is also "very favorable" with small reproductions near the quarry of La Baña, which have been "resolved without problem". Its perimeter is also in consolidation phase and with an active surveillance with means against fires.
"There has only been, in the highest area, on the border between Zamora and León, some complication in which we have worked to contain its advance since there has been a lot of wind, but at the moment it is also in a situation of stabilization", he detailed.
During the afternoon this Thursday there has also been a fire in Torre de Babia, in the region of Villablino, which is at level 0.
For all these reasons, the territorial delegate has stressed that the outlook is positive as the situation of the fires evolves "very well" after these 21 days in which there have been moments of "hard work and intensity due to the volume of fires".
"To give us an idea, right now we have ten stabilized fires, controlled or extinguished, which have occurred in the last 20 days and have had reached level 2," he explained, to then point out that in 2024 in the whole summer there were only two fires in severity 2.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RH83-S7T3-N069-00000-00CECOPI is dissolved due to "favorable" evolution in León after downgrading the Fasgar-Colinas fire to IGR 12025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisCECOPI is dissolved due to "favorable" evolution in León after downgrading the Fasgar-Colinas fire to IGR 1


The fire situation in León is "very favorable" after a night of low temperatures and rain which has allowed the Fasgar-Colinas fire, which was the only one remaining in Potential Severity Index (IGR) 2 in Castilla y León, has been lowered to severity 1, so it has proceeded to dissolve the provincial CECOPI, since the regional was dissolved on Friday afternoon.


This has been moved by the territorial delegate of the Board in the province, Eduardo Diego, after the CECOPI meeting held this morning, which has detailed that the fire has been lowered to severity level 1 Fasgar and Hills, therefore it has been discontinued CECOPI provincial as the situation has improved "substantially" as there are no more fires of severity 2.
Thus, the forest fire of Fasgar and Hills has experienced a "very favorable" evolution during the night due to low temperatures and drizzle, which have helped to slow the progress of the outbreaks that were active in the area of Tremor de Arriba, but now remains to work on consolidation of the perimeter.
For its part, in the fire in severity 1 of Llamas de Cabrera, the weather has also contributed to consolidate the perimeter of the west area and work continues on techniques and functions of liquidation of this fire.
In the case of the Barniedo de la Reina fire, the perimeter is also stabilized and with reproductions which are being attended by the means available in the area, and work is also being carried out to consolidate the perimeter.
The representative of the Autonomous Executive in the province has also pointed out that the fire of La Baña, which is also in IGR 1, has registered a "very favorable" evolution during the last hours, although there have been small reproductions near the quarry of La Baña that have been solved "without major problems".
"Therefore we can say that the situation is very favorable and positive, we no longer have fires that threaten populations or evacuated or confined populations," he added.
However, Diego has assured that at this time "you can not lower our guard" as there are stabilized fires in which means are maintained deployed to perform consolidation work perimeter and surveillance, as long as "the risk of reproduction has not disappeared."
He also took advantage of the last meeting of the provincial CECOPI to thank the entire operation, the institutions and administrations involved and the State Security Forces and Corps, UME and Defense, for their work during evacuations and confinements, but also in research work of the various fires.

urn:contentItem:6GP6-0J33-RV94-V1W0-00000-00Firefighters put out a fire at the Chapada dos Veadeiros portal2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisFirefighters put out a fire at the Chapada dos Veadeiros portal

The forest fire that threatened to hit the Condomínio Habitat ecovillage in the municipality of São João d'Aliança-G0, in the Chapada dos Veadeiros, has been brought under control by local firefighters. Also on Thursday night (4/9), flames were spotted in the São Pedro Valley, a vast region with countless waterfalls and more than 10,000km² of preserved Cerrado. The municipal fire brigade acted throughout Friday (5/9), from morning until night, and managed to keep out the blazes that were approaching rural homes. At the height of the blaze, the flames reached the ground cover of a farm and caused a thick column of smoke. According to Nasa satellite images, it is estimated that around 12km² of native vegetation was damaged by the fire, which is still active in another direction. Also on Friday, Correio contacted the Municipal Environment Secretariat requesting information on the impacts of the incident, the investigation into the incident and the budget for actions to prevent and combat forest fires, but did not hear back.

The space remains open and will be updated as soon as the issues are clarified. Local sources, however, suspect that the fire was caused by cattle farmers, who adopt the harmful and outdated practice as a way of renewing pastures. Participants in the municipality's Environmental Conference also highlight the need for greater investment in preventative measures and in the brigade's structure, with more staff and equipment, to tackle arson.
Silza Freire, a socio-environmental entrepreneur, art therapist and head of Espaço Ecologia Viva, located in a reserve area in the Serra do Paranã, recounts the terror caused by forest fires in the Cerrado and calls for more support to prevent further occurrences. "We need to continue preserving springs and local biodiversity, but every year we are at risk of fire during the dry season. We make a protective barrier here, but we lack the support to get appropriate safety equipment to fight fires. Last year, I fought the fire using only a flashlight on my cell phone and branches to put it out. I took several falls on the rocks, but I didn't give up and kept putting it out. The firefighters didn't arrive until almost two hours later, because they were on another job," she says.
A resident of the region and also a socio-environmental entrepreneur, lawyer Aleska Ferro, a delegate at the National Environment Conference and a representative of the Environmental Law and Sustainability Commission of the OAB Formosa, reinforces the need for greater attention to be paid to the Cerrado in São João d'Aliança. "In addition to the loss of biodiversity and water contamination, we face serious structural problems: inadequate waste disposal, illegal burning, excessive use of pesticides and deforestation in sensitive areas, such as the banks of the Vereda stream, which is now at risk of disappearing. The solutions necessarily involve environmental education: workshops in schools, companies and farms, joint efforts and listening groups. Also through local cultural appreciation and keeping people in the countryside, with qualified and aware labor, public-private and university partnerships to apply ESG (Environmental, Social and Governance) practices, as well as mechanisms for effective compensation for environmental damage," he points out. urn:contentItem:6GP6-0J33-RV94-V177-00000-00The highest altitude stadium of Copa Peru 2025 is almost 4,000 m.a.s.l. and could be used for professional soccer in 2026.2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisThe highest altitude stadium of Copa Peru 2025 is almost 4,000 m.a.s.l. and could be used for professional soccer in 2026.

The highest altitude stadium of CopaPeru 2025 is almost 4,000 m.a.s.l. and could be used for professional soccer in 2026.The National Stage of the Peru Cup 2025 is about to begin and will give us stadiums with different qualities. One of them stands out for being located at an altitude of several meters above sea level.

Copa Peru teams dispute pass to the final stage in the middle of a forest fire: unexpected phenomenon spread during the match

Assault on reporter in Copa Peru sparks pitched battle between police and players in Chota

Emilio Carranza
With the start of the National Stage of the Peru Cup 2025 getting closer and closer, it is essential to highlight some of the sports venues where the matches will be played. Several of them are marked by the high temperatures, the striking geography or the demanding altitude in which they are located.


If there is one thing there is no doubt, it is that the teams will seek to take advantage of every "advantage" of their cities, since several of these scenarios are really complicated. This is the case, for example, of the Estadio Polideportivo de Azángaro, where the San Martín Tour club plays its home games.
The imperious stadium with one of the highest heights in the Copa Peru.
Located in the Puno region, the Estadio Polideportivo Azángaro will be one of the most difficult venues for any club, as it is located above 3,850 m. a. s. n. m. It was inaugurated just 7 years ago, specifically in 2018.
In addition, it has synthetic turf and can receive just over seven thousand spectators in the two stands that the stadium has. As if that were not enough, it can host night matches, since it has 60 floodlights.
It will be up to San Martín Tour to get its stadium into League 2 in 2026. For the time being, it will have to beat Instituto Apurímac in its debut in the National Stage of the Peruvian Cup.
Which are the 64 clubs that have qualified for the National Stage of the Copa Peru 2025?
Here are the teams that had a remarkable performance in the departmental phase and earned the right to play in the National Stage of the Peru Cup 2025.

urn:contentItem:6GFB-XB73-RS1T-71P1-00000-00August starts with air quality alerts in NH2025-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSAugust starts with air quality alerts in NHElijah de CastroThe Keene Sentinel, N.H.

Smoke from wildfires in Canada is bringing unsafe levels of fine particle pollution to the Monadnock Region for the second time this summer.

The N.H. Department of Environmental Services declared an air quality action day for Cheshire and Sullivan counties Wednesday, citing pollution from high concentrations of fine particles from the wildfires. In a news release, the state agency said this type of pollution is expected to reach unhealthy levels for sensitive individuals in these counties, in Grafton County, and at elevations above 2,000 feet. Sensitive groups include people with asthma, people who are elderly and children.

Air quality alerts have been issued throughout the Northeast and Midwest, and the pollution was expected to continue over the following days. Wednesday’s alert in New Hampshire followed one the state issued the day before.

“Even healthy individuals may experience mild health effects and should consider limiting strenuous or prolonged outdoor activities,” the department said in a news release Tuesday.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, which monitors wildfires throughout the country, said there were 737 active wildfires as of Tuesday afternoon, most of which were considered out of control.

urn:contentItem:6GJT-F0N3-RY3H-P0XC-00000-00Warning to Brit tourists as holiday hotspots hit by worst summer for wildfires on record2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWarning to Brit tourists as holiday hotspots hit by worst summer for wildfires on recordRebecca Robinson

Europe has experienced the worst summer on record for wildfires.

Wildfires have scorched over one million hectares across Europe this year, marking 2025 as the most devastating summer on record. Deadly blazes have consumed four times as much land this year compared to the average for the same period over the past two decades, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System . EFFIS revealed that 1,015,024 hectares have been burnt this year, surpassing the previous record of 988,544 hectares set in 2017.

The fires have released 37 million tonnes of carbon dioxide – roughly equivalent to the annual CO2 output of Portugal or Sweden. They have also shattered records for this period of the year across nine additional air pollutants, including fine particles termed PM2.5 that researchers say make wildfires considerably more lethal than previously understood.

Wildfires have been exacerbated by dry conditions.

Cristina Santín Nuño, a fire scientist at the Spanish National Research Council, explained that the "perfect conditions" for large wildfires were occurring increasingly frequently due to climate change and changes in land usage.

Wildfires tore across vast areas of southern Europe this month as temperatures went beyond 40C throughout much of the Mediterranean and the Balkans.

This dried out vegetation, which in countries such as Spain and Portugal had flourished following a damp spring, allowing fires to burn more intensely and spread further.

The flames are confirmed to have claimed more than a dozen lives but scientists warn the actual death toll is likely to be higher.

Dense clouds of smoke will have contaminated people's lungs with dangerous gases and poisonous particles tiny enough to penetrate the bloodstream.

On Tuesday, the Copernicus atmosphere monitoring service discovered that "unprecedented" fire activity this year had taken Spain's wildfire emissions to the highest annual total in the 23 years since records began.

Toxic fumes from blazes across the Iberian peninsula were worsened by smoke drifting across the Atlantic from Canada, which has also suffered severe burning in recent weeks.

Wildfire emissions from Spain and Portugal in August have been "exceptional", said Mark Parrington, a scientist with Copernicus.

EFFIS said on Tuesday that fire weather conditions were expected to ease across most of southern Europe this week, but added that "very high to very extreme" anomalies were expected in north-west Europe.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2T03-RTJV-21RH-00000-00Deforestation fuels flood risks2025-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisDeforestation fuels flood risks

The recent devastating floods in Punjab have reignited the debate over the province's meagre forest cover, with experts warning that it has amplified the scale of destruction.

Environmentalists note that forests play a vital role in absorbing rainwater, slowing down runoff and preventing soil erosion.

Punjab's forest cover stands far below global standards.

According to the United Nations benchmarks, at least 25 per cent of a country's land should be under forest cover, while in Punjab only 3.1% land is categorised as forested.

The Punjab Forest Department states that the province has a total forest area of 1.663 million acres, dominated by scrub forests (41%), while private farmlands contribute 27% through plantation. The rest includes riverine areas, rangelands and coniferous patches.

Provincial Forest Department Director General Azfar Zia said large-scale plantation drives were under way with 51 million saplings planned to be planted on 40,000 acres.

The target for the ongoing monsoon season is 21 million saplings over 25,000 acres, with 6.5 million already planted.

"In the spring plantation campaign, we exceeded the target by planting more than 10.5 million saplings," Zia added, noting that agroforestry initiatives are also engaging farmers to plant trees on their lands.

Official record shows that Punjab's forest area has grown from around 701,000 acres in 2013 to 1.263 million acres, while barren land has dropped from 960,000 acres to 399,000 acres.

However, experts argue that the progress remains insufficient. They point out that raising forest cover by even 1% would require around 43 new forests the size of Changa Manga, land for which the province does not have available.

The National Project Director at the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), Asim Jamal, said that of Punjab's forested land, only 0.45% is actually tree-covered.

He stressed that reforestation of the land was crucial. "Farmers and landowners must be convinced that trees enhance soil fertility, protect crops from disasters, and can even generate income through carbon markets," he added.

According to the World Wide Fund for Nature-Pakistan (WWF-Pakistan), the country loses about 11,000 hectares of forest every year. The main drivers include unchecked logging, wildfires, climate change and conversion of forest land for agriculture and commercial use.

WWF-Pakistan Director General Hammad Naqi Khan said, "Forest protection is not just an environmental necessity, it is an economic imperative."

He warned that large-scale felling of mature trees is compounding ecological losses, while shrinking green spaces in cities are intensifying urban flooding.

He called for stronger protection of mature trees alongside afforestation and urban greening measures.

The forest department says it is deploying modern technology for monitoring and protection. Satellite-based GIS monitoring now covers 67% of Punjab's forest area, while AI-powered drones are used for wildfire surveillance. In 2024, 269 forest fire incidents damaged 6,500 acres, but in 2025, the number of cases dropped to 200 with damage reduced to 2,500 acres.

Provincial Senior Minister Mariyyum Aurangzeb said Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz has, for the first time, banned the traditional auction system of forest timber.

The new policy aims to curb illegal logging through transparent, technology-based monitoring and mapping. The government insists that the move is not only crucial for tree protection but also vital for reducing soil erosion.

Experts, however, emphasize that large-scale afforestation in Punjab is constrained by land scarcity.

urn:contentItem:6GJK-FX93-RSPP-80GD-00000-00Spain contains worst wildfires in decades, though some still burning2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisNEWSSpain contains worst wildfires in decades, though some still burningSPAIN WILDFIRESABSTRACT

Madrid, Aug 22 (EFE).- Spain has begun bringing under control its most devastating wave of wildfires this century, extinguishing several major blazes and stabilizing the spread of flames thanks to improved weather, though 19 fires remain active in the north and west.

FULL TEXT

Madrid, Aug 22 (EFE).- Spain has begun bringing under control its most devastating wave of wildfires this century, extinguishing several major blazes and stabilizing the spread of flames thanks to improved weather, though 19 fires remain active in the north and west.

Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez announced Friday the start of a "path" toward a state pact against wildfires, alongside plans to launch an inter-ministerial commission on climate change on Tuesday to address the crisis.

During a visit to Asturias, one of the hardest-hit regions, Sánchez said he would take the issue to the next Conference of Presidents, the top political forum between the central government and Spain's regions, before the end of the year to "define and implement policies for prevention, response and reconstruction."

The Interior Ministry reported Friday that 19 fires remain active at Operational Situation 2, the second-highest emergency level, across Castilla y León (11), Galicia (6) and Extremadura (1).

According to the forestry platform edu.forestry.es, based on the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), Galicia and Castilla y León account for 79 percent of all burned land, with 51 "major fires," those exceeding 500 hectares, recorded so far.

Improved conditions overnight Thursday allowed crews to consolidate fire perimeters and prevent flare-ups.

This included stabilizing the Jarilla fire in Extremadura after 11 days of burning, which scorched more than 17,000 hectares across a 170-km perimeter, the largest in the region's recent history.

Although temperatures rose slightly on Friday, authorities said the absence of strong winds should allow firefighting work to progress steadily.

The state has deployed all national forest brigades under the Ministry for the Ecological Transition, supported by 45 aircraft conducting daily water drops.

The Military Emergency Unit maintains 1,400 personnel on the ground, backed by another 1,000 troops from the armed forces.

Meanwhile, police and Civil Guard units remain focused on safeguarding residents, assisting with evacuations, more than 33,000 people since the pre-emergency phase, and supporting the gradual resettlement of families in safe areas. EFE nav-sk

urn:contentItem:6GF7-1G13-S1N4-00YP-00000-00Smoke from Canada wildfires prompt air quality alerts in US: See map2025-08-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & CANADA NEWSSmoke from Canada wildfires prompt air quality alerts in US: See mapChristopher Cann and Karina Zaiets, USA TODAY

Large wildfires in Canada continued to cause concerning air quality levels across parts of the United States and triggered multiple air quality alerts.

Over 750 wildfires are burning throughout Canada, with more than 500 labeled out of control, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. Over 16 million acres of land have been scorched by blazes, making this year's wildfire season one of Canada's worst on record.

Smoke from the blazes has crossed into the United States, bringing hazy skies to multiple states and major metropolitan areas, including New York City. As of Aug. 6, the Environmental Protection Agency labeled air quality throughout the Plains, Midwest and Northeast regions as "unhealthy for sensitive groups," including the city of Chicago.

More: Feathery suspect (and its fishy accomplice) responsible for starting brush fire in Canada

The National Weather Service issued air quality alerts in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, Illinois, Pennsylvania, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Massachusetts. The alerts warned those with asthma and heart issues to take precautions to avoid fatigue and strenuous outdoor activity.

urn:contentItem:6GK6-J3B3-RRM6-72JV-00000-00Music and film star delights crowd of thousands at North Yorkshire venue2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisMusic and film star delights crowd of thousands at North Yorkshire venueHaydn Lewis

CROWDS went wild for an Oscar winning actor and chart-topping rapper at a top North Yorkshire venue.

On Sunday night (August 24) Will Smith brought his Based on a True Story European Tour to the UK-s biggest open-air concert arena in Scarborough to the delight of 8,000 fans.

Recommended reading:

Forest fire started deliberately in North Yorkshire Emergency crews called to two people stuck on North Yorkshire cliff Woman wanted by police after shoplifting offences in North Yorkshire

Crowds watching Will Smith at Scarborough Open Air Theatre (Image: Jim Cooke, Cuffe and Taylor) The show at Scarborough Open Air Theatre (OAT) charted Will-s life from his days in the music charts as the Fresh Prince, through his acclaimed movie career - and he delighted fans new and old.

He played a hit-laden set which included such classics as Gettin- Jiggy Wit It, Miami, Summertime, Wild Wild West, Bulletproof and Men In Black for which he was backed by 30 members of Scarborough Rugby Club - all dressed as the inter-stellar secret agents from Will-s hit Sci-fi movie.

-This has been a beautiful night and I want to thank you all from the bottom of my heart,- an emotional Will told the capacity crowd before bringing out his Best Actor Academy Award to deafening applause.

Will Smith delighted fans at Scarborough Open Air Theatre (Image: Jim Cooke, Cuffe and Taylor) He added: -This night is particularly joyful for me as I-ve had some difficulties in the last couple of years.

"I-ve spent my entire career trying to bring joy and fun and love. It-s been my deepest human devotion to bring a little bit of light and love into this world.-

Opening the show were BBC Radio One-s Melvin Odoom and Rickie Haywood-Williams before BBC 2 Radio 2 breakfast host Scott Mills and traffic and travel presenter Ellie Brennan - whose Scarborough-themed version of Will-s classic hit Miami has become a viral hit - got the crowd warmed up.

Scott Mills at Scarborough OAT (Image: Jim Cooke, Cuffe and Taylor) This summer-s shows at Scarborough OAT have brought more than 100,000 gig goers to the historic Yorkshire coast venue for headline performances from the likes of The Smashing Pumpkins, Gary Barlow, Snow Patrol, Blossoms, McFly and Judas Priest.

Will Smith on stage at the OAT (Image: Jim Cooke, Cuffe and Taylor)

urn:contentItem:6GMH-WCR3-RV30-C3N5-00000-00Wildfires sweep Spain, Portugal and Greece during unremitting heatwave2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWildfires sweep Spain, Portugal and Greece during unremitting heatwave

Firefighters in Spain, Portugal and Greece are battling fierce wildfires as scorching, dry, intense heat fuels blazes across the region, coinciding with major religious holidays, as global warming leaves its mark on Europe.

Spain faced 14 major fires on Friday, said Virginia Barcones, the emergency services chief, as temperatures were forecast to rise further over the weekend.

'Today will once again be a very tough day with an extreme risk of new fires,' Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez warned on Friday.

The State Meteorological Agency placed most of the country under extreme fire danger alerts, particularly in the north and west, where the largest blazes raged. The current heatwave, with temperatures topping 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) on several days this month, is expected to linger until Monday.

In Galicia, fires shut down several highways and halted high-speed rail services to Madrid. The EU's European Forest Fire Information System reported that wildfires in Spain this year have already burned 158,000 hectares (390,000 acres), an area the size of metropolitan London.

Friday marked the Feast of the Assumption in Spain and Portugal, a major Catholic holiday usually observed with family gatherings and processions.

The fires raging across Portugal caused a first fatality Friday, when the former mayor of the eastern town of Planta died fighting fires there, President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa announced.

The president offered 'heartfelt condolences to the mayor of Guarda for the death of former mayor Carlos Damaso, victim of a fire he was fighting in his parish, asking that he pass them on to his family', the president's statement said.

Almost 4,000 firefighters battled seven active fires in Portugal, as authorities extended a state of alert until Sunday. The government also sought European Union assistance under its civil protection mechanism.

A day earlier, Spain received two Canadair water bomber aircraft from the European Union, the first time it had ever activated the bloc's emergency firefighting aid.

Elsewhere in Southern Europe, Greece continued to struggle with a major wildfire burning for four days on the island of Chios. Several overnight evacuations took place as flames spread through the island's northern region. Two planes and two helicopters dropped water during calmer winds early on Friday.

After devastating fires earlier this week in western Greece, the fire service remained on high alert outside Athens and in southern areas, where strong winds and high temperatures heightened the danger.

Across the Balkans and Southern Europe, demand for the EU's shared firefighting resources has soared this year. Bulgaria, Montenegro and Albania have all called for help in recent days as the system has already been deployed as often as during the whole of last year's fire season.

Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, the spiritual head of the world's Orthodox Christians, expressed solidarity with wildfire victims during prayers for the Dormition of the Virgin Mary, one of the faith's most significant feast days.

urn:contentItem:6GSB-JC33-RRHP-X3MX-00000-00Hakan Çalhanoğlu and My Lovely Planet Launch the “Çalhanoğlu Forest”: 50 Soccer Fields of Trees in Turkey2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisCOMPANY ANNOUNCEMENTHakan Çalhanoğlu and My Lovely Planet Launch the “Çalhanoğlu Forest”: 50 Soccer Fields of Trees in TurkeyTurkish football legend Hakan Çalhanoğlu has taken equity in the award-winning Web3 mobile game, recognized by Google Play Store after planting 380,000 trees worldwide.

New YorkNY, Sept. 18, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Together, they launch the #PlayForTurkey campaign, where trees planted in the game are also planted in real life.

My Lovely Planet (MLP), the Web3 mobile game that transforms gameplay into real-world impact, has announced a major partnership with international football star Hakan Çalhanoğlu and his wife Sinem Çalhanoğlu. Together, they are launching the Çalhanoğlu Forest, a large-scale reforestation initiative in Turkey, where every in-game action contributes to planting real trees. 

“Football has given me so much, and now I want to give something back, not just to my country, but to the world,” said Hakan Çalhanoğlu. “With My Lovely Planet, fans can have fun and directly join me in bringing impact while enjoying the game. Together, we can make gaming meaningful.”

My Lovely Planet is no ordinary mobile game. Built by the gaming veterans behind Candy Crush, Royal Match, and Fortnite, and selected by Google (#WeArePlay), the game combines world-class entertainment with a powerful mission: every in-game achievement funds the planting of real trees. Designed to be as addictive and fun as Candy Crush, My Lovely Planet adds a unique twist, players actively contribute to the fight against climate change simply by playing.

“We’re building more than a game. We’re building a movement where entertainment fuels real-world action. The Kuşadası project is just the beginning – and partnering with Hakan allows us to inspire millions of fans to make a difference, one download at a time,” said Clément Le Bras, Founder and CEO of My Lovely Planet.

The Çalhanoğlu Forest: Rebuilding After the Fires

The first project under this partnership will take place on the reforestation site in Kuşadası, Aydın Province, an area devastated by a forest fire on June 29, 2024. The project will be led on site with the Turkish Tohum Association (Tohum Eğitim Kültür ve Doğa Derneği).

Phase 1: Immediate planting of 10,000 saplings financed by Hakan Çalhanoğlu, covering about 50 football fields

Phase 2: Now it’s your turn! Play the game and plant your own tree alongside Hakan and Sinem Çalhanoğlu’s. The more you play My Lovely Planet, the more trees will grow together!

Species Mix: To ensure longevity of the trees, only native resilient tree species are planted including Turkish pine (Pinus brutia), oak (Quercus spp.), and select fruit/value trees

Each project is carried out with professional site preparation, active community involvement, and long-term monitoring to ensure lasting success.

Through the #PlayForTurkey campaign, trees planted in the game will result in real trees being planted in the Çalhanoğlu Forest.

On top of that, many more exciting surprises are coming soon, making it clear that gaming can be both fun and meaningful.

About My Lovely Planet

My Lovely Planet (MLP) is a pioneering Web3 Mobile Game that fuses addictive, social gameplay with tangible climate action. Developed by a team of gaming veterans from Candy Crush, Royal Match, and Fortnite, and selected by Google (#WeArePlay), MLP is on a mission to prove that fun and purpose can go hand in hand. Every in-game achievement translates into real trees planted, making entertainment a force for global good.

urn:contentItem:6GMP-6DR3-S15R-808P-00000-00Fire in Holbox consumes 400 hectares of the island: could not be controlled after eight days active | Videos2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisFire in Holbox consumes 400 hectares of the island: could not be controlled after eight days active | Videos


A forest fire that has been active for eight days in the Yum Balam reserve, located in the municipality of Lázaro Cárdenas, on the island of Holbox, Quintana Roo, has already consumed 400 hectares and represents a threat to protected species such as the jaguar and tapir.


While brigadistas and authorities reinforce actions to stop the advance of the flames, the magnitude of the fire and the adverse conditions make it difficult to protect one of the most valuable ecosystems in the region.
The actions
According to official reports, the fire is now 50% under control and 40% extinguished, as a result of the coordinated intervention of 80 elements of the Navy, the National Forestry Commission (CONAFOR), the National Commission of Protected Natural Areas (CONANP), as well as state and municipal aid agencies.
The deployment of resources includes the use of a Mi-17 helicopter equipped with a helibald, which continuously discharges water over the active outbreaks, as well as a Bell 407 helicopter, three vehicles, a Civil Protection vehicle, four boats, the opening of firebreaks and the application of counter-fires. Patrolling, surveillance and reconnaissance flights remain constant to prevent the fire from spreading.
⇒⇒ State authorities have urged the population to avoid any activity that could originate new fire outbreaks in the region. ⇐⇐
Municipal authorities have announced the hiring of more personnel to work on the opening of firebreaks, as well as the acquisition of necessary machinery, such as chainsaws and machetes. The institutions involved have reiterated their commitment to maintain the firefighting work uninterrupted until the fire is completely controlled.
Brigaders are facing difficulties due to weather conditions. The persistent drought in the area of the inlet, coupled with strong winds, hinders the progress of firefighting efforts, although other communities in the municipality have experienced heavy rains. This combination of factors keeps the risk high and requires maximum cooperation from the population.
Protected area at risk
While several communities in the municipality report rainfall, the extreme dryness and winds in the affected area continue to hinder the work of the brigadistas, who are trying to contain the fire and protect the area's biodiversity.
The Yum Balam reserve, with an area of 154,000 hectares, is a protected natural area with a diversity of ecosystems, including jungles, mangroves, dunes, and lagoons.
This environment is home to a wide variety of flora and fauna species at risk, including jaguars and tapirs, sea turtles such as loggerhead and hawksbill turtles, American and swamp crocodiles, flamingos, jabiru storks, roseate spoonbills, spider monkeys, pumas, ocelots, ocelots, margays and manatees.
In the inlet area, the presence of chit palm and grape sea trees, both of which are listed as protected species, raises concerns about the ecological impact of the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GKW-5TY3-S3TD-615P-00000-00Wildfires pile pressure on embattled Spanish PM2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWildfires pile pressure on embattled Spanish PM

WILDFIRES t hat have swept across Spain this summer are piling pressure on Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, who is already reeling from a string of corruption allegations against members of his inner circle.

the twin crises have intensified disputes between Sanchez's Socialist minority government and the conservative Popular Party (PP), which governs many of the regions hardest hit by the fires. Blazes have destroyed more than 415,000 hectares, mostly in August, according to the European Forest Fire Information System, marking a new annual record since reporting began in 2006. Four people have died and thousands have been evacuated because of this month's fires. The Socialists blame the PP for failing to implement effective fire prevention policies and for playing down climate change.

the PP points to arson as the cause of the fires and accuses the central government of withholding resources, including enough military support. PP leader Alberto Núñez Feijóo has proposed creating a national registry of arsonists. But government minister Angel Victor Torres insisted on public television on Wednesday that regional governments were responsible for disaster response. 'The opposition leader shows up and points fingers instead of helping,' he said, referring to the proposed arson registry. Defence Minister Margarita Robles said many PP-led regional governments had 'failed to act'. 'When there has been no investment in prevention, it is not enough to say, 'The army will arrive,'' she told radio station Ser. PP spokeswoman Ester Munoz countered, accusing the government of scapegoating. 'The response of a 'serious government should be 'where and when do you need resources' and not that local authorities are incompetent,' she said.

the political debate mirrors the controversy that followed deadly floods in October 2024 in PP-governed Valencia. The row comes as Sanchez's politicalstanding has taken a hit from several investigations into alleged corruption among his inner circle. His wife, Begona Gomez, has been ordered to appear in court again in September for questioning into alleged embezzlement of public funds. Sanchez has dismissed the allegations against his wife - which are related to her past job at Madrid's Complutense University - as an attempt by the right to undermine his government.

the prime minister's former right-hand man, Santos Cerdan, was detained in June in an ongoing probe into alleged kickbacks for public contracts.

and his younger brother, David Sanchez, has been under investigation since 2024 for alleged embezzlement, influence peddling and tax fraud. Sanchez's minority government is propped up by smaller regional parties and it has struggled to pass legislation or even a budget. Feijoo has dismissed Sanchez as a 'zombie' head of government because of his difficulty in passing laws and called for an early general election

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DFT3-RRR5-S2N7-00000-00With 15 active outbreaks, the situation is improving although there is still a high risk of new fires.2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWith 15 active outbreaks, the situation is improving although there is still a high risk of new fires.


Spain still maintains very high levels of risk of new fires and although control of the situation is improving, there are still worrying outbreaks, with 15 fires in operational situation 2, ten of them in Castilla y León (León and Zamora), three in Asturias and one in Orense (Galicia), according to data provided by the State Coordination Committee (CECOD) against fires, to which must be added a new one declared this afternoon by the Junta in Garaño (León).


The scenario is "favorable but very slow", said this Sunday the general director of Civil Protection, Virginia Barcones, who warned that "the teams are beginning to be strongly exhausted", after fifteen days of aggressive and virulent fires.
In addition, the fire danger remains "at very high or extreme levels" in large areas of the peninsula, especially in the north, center and southeast, warns the State Meteorological Agency.
Related to this topicNew day of firefighting in Spain: more evictions and still worrying outbreaks
According to weather forecasts, a DANA located in the southwest of the peninsula with uncertainty about its trajectory will move predictably by the peninsular south and will cause locally strong showers and / or storms in the Pyrenees today and possibly also in other points of the eastern third.
Maximum temperatures will fall in the Canary Islands and in the interior of the eastern third and increase in the southwest quadrants, upper Ebro and the Ampurdán, without significant changes in the rest. Could exceed 35 degrees in the Guadalquivir, and locally in the Guadiana, Tajo and Ebro.
Situation in Castilla y León
Castilla y León begins the third week fighting forest fires with six fires that remain in potential severity index 2, the maximum level, and two declared this Sunday, after a positive evolution that has allowed lowering the level of six other although the rise in temperatures, accompanied by a drop in humidity and wind, again complicate the situation.
Leon continues to focus the concerns with five level 2 fires, those declared in Fasgar, La Baña, Igüeña, Garaño and Molinaseca -with favorable evolution-, the latter two emerged this Sunday, with great virulence and forced to evacuate eleven localities, bringing to twelve the number of evacuated with more than 700 affected.
Related to this topicFrom catastrophe to opportunity: forestry experts see feasible to recover a good part of the 400,000 hectares of burned land
Adhik Arrilucea

The reactivations in the face of rising temperatures, with the consequent drop in humidity, and the wind that remains persistent in some areas, with changes of direction, have marked the last hours in the fight against the fire, rekindling for example the fire of Fasgar.
On the other hand, the favorable evolution of some fires has allowed to lower the level of severity. Thus, the Junta de Castilla y León has lowered from level 2 to level 1 the fires of Anllares del Sil, Llamas de Cabrera, Barniedo de la Reina and Gestoso, in León, and that of Cardaño de Arriba in Palencia. And from level 1 to 0 the Canalejas fire (Almansa).
Related to this topicThe fire lowers its intensity in Castilla y León while in Ourense seven fires are still active.
The Board has indicated, in a press release, that the fires that have descended level are without flame, do not pose risk to the population or maintain cuts in the road network, but remain under close surveillance to stop the reproductions that could occur, and cooling work is maintained until final control.
The Porto fire (Zamora), which has improved its evolution after entering the Natural Park of Lago de Sanabria and passing to León in La Baña, is still at the maximum level of severity, together with the five fires in León. It is precisely its transfer to León, with risk for the population of the area of La Baña, which keeps it at level 2, given that most of the Zamora perimeter is under control.
Related to this topicWeather gives a respite in the extinction of fires in Galicia, Castile and Leon and Extremadura
The fires in Yeres -which affected the natural area of Las Médulas, a World Heritage Site-; Resoba, in Montaña Palentina; Molezuelas de la Carballeda, where three people lost their lives; San Pedro de Cansoles; Brañosera; and Candelario, in the province of Cáceres- are still active but not serious.
The forest fire extinction operation will continue this Monday pending the evolution of the meteorological conditions, due to the increase of temperatures, and from the Junta de Castilla y León it is again alerted that some of the fires declared in the last hours, and which are under investigation, could be intentional, which complicates the extinction tasks.
Evolution of the fire in Galicia
Galicia has this Monday three active forest fires, all in the province of Ourense, where on Sunday a new fire broke out in the municipality of Avión, and presents favorable evolution of Chandrexa de Queixa, with only one active focus.
Related to this topicCourage, but also taxes: this is how the UME, firefighters and neighbors have put an end to the flames
The last balance of Rural Environment updates the area burned in Avión, with a fire declared on Sunday afternoon in the parish of Nieva that has devastated 70 hectares.
The fire in Chandrexa de Queixa, which started the wave of fires on August 8 and has devastated 19,000 hectares, is still active. Its evolution is favorable, because only the focus of Vilariño remains active.
Also active is the fire of Carballeda de Valdeorras, parish of Casaio, which entered from Porto de Sanabria (Zamora) and has burned 4,400 hectares, including Pena Trevinca, the highest peak in Galicia.
The Larouco fire, the largest in the history of Galicia with 30,000 hectares burned, remains stabilized since Saturday.
Those of Oímbra and Xinzo de Limia (17.000 ha), A Mezquita-A Esculqueira (10,000 ha), Carballeda de Avia and Beade (4,000 ha), Vilardevós-Vilar de Cervos (900 ha) and Vilaboa-Santa Cristina de Cobres (70 ha).Related to this topicAemet confirms that the recent heat wave has been the most intense so far in Spain
In situation of "controlled" are the fires of Maceda (3,500 ha), Vilardevós-Moialde (600 ha), Montederramo-Paredes (120 ha), Riós-Trasestrada (40 ha), Riós-Fumaces and A Trepa (100 ha) and Carballedo- A Cova (100 ha).
The wave of fires that began on August 8 in Galicia has already devastated almost 92,000 hectares, according to data from Rural Environment, which only reports fires of more than 20 hectares or affecting protected areas.
The Xunta maintains active situation 2 throughout the province of Ourense, although no new confinements or evacuations have been carried out.
Favorable development of the fire in Andalusia
The Operational Service for the Extinction of Forest Fires of Andalusia (Infoca) has considered controlled about 24 hours after the fire declared on Saturday night in a place located between the capital and Cenes de la Vega that forced at the beginning to cut traffic in the area.
According to information provided by the Infoca, the plan has been controlled the fire at 21.00 hours this past Sunday, a day after a first flame of fire in the area of the Fuente de la Bicha gave the alarm.
Two groups of forest firefighters, an agent of the Environment and two fire engines are working on the tasks for the finish and liquidation.
The fire started after 21.00 hours this past Saturday in a forest area near the Serrallo tunnels, between Granada capital and Cenes de la Vega, and affects a hillside near the river Genil.
The forest fire, which has also mobilized firefighters from the South and North parks of Granada, Civil Guard, Local Police and Civil Protection, caused during the night of Saturday the closure to traffic of the A-395, the road to Sierra Nevada, reopened on Sunday with normality.
Controlled the fire in Jarilla (Cáceres)
The Plan to Combat Forest Fires in Extremadura (Infoex) has given controlled at 21:00 hours this past Sunday, August 24, the forest fire in Jarilla (Cáceres) declared last August 12 and deactivates the level 1 of danger, to move to level zero.
In the area remain two units of forest firefighters, four agents of the Natural Environment and an extinguishing technician.
Thirteen days after the fire started, it has been possible to control this devastating fire, the largest in the history of Extremadura, which has burned 17,355 hectares in a perimeter of 170 kilometers.
The fire was stabilized this Friday, the Infoex level 2 was deactivated, downgraded to level 1, and the Advanced Command Post of 112 Extremadura, which has been coordinating the emergency operation these days, as well as external means that have collaborated in the tasks for its control and extinction, was withdrawn.
The Junta de Extremadura declared this Saturday the total deactivation of the Special Plan for Civil Protection against Forest Fires in Extremadura (INFOCAEX), after neutralizing the Jarilla fire, in which Infoex own means have remained dedicated to consolidation tasks of the stabilized perimeter.
This Friday could return to their homes the neighbors of the houses of the periurban area of Hervás, as well as the isolated houses of Jerte, Tornavacas, Cabezuela and Navaconcejo after declining the evacuation that weighed on them, a measure that during the previous days has been affecting other municipalities depending on the progress of the fire, such as Jarilla, Cabezabellosa, Villar de Plasencia or Rebollar.
In the most critical moments of the fire, half a thousand troops and about thirty aerial means fought against the flames that have burned thousands of hectares in the regions of Valle del Jerte and Ambroz, even entering the Castilian province of Salamanca.

urn:contentItem:6GPM-YTV3-RVY1-K052-00000-00Wildfires should start regionalization conversation, says Municipalities N.L.2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWSWildfires should start regionalization conversation, says Municipalities N.L.

Municipalities N.L. is renewing its call for regionalization after a summer of wildfires highlighted the issues unincorporated communities face during emergencies - including a lack of emergency services and communication from a point person.

To fill those gaps during the Kingston wildfire in Conception Bay North, members of the town of Small Point-Adam's Cove-Blackhead-Broad Cove stepped up.

"Their council actually volunteered to go into their neighbouring communities after the fact to assess the damage," said Municipalities N.L. CEO Rob Nolan. "That's an example of what happens when you don't have elected leadership to go in to speak for those communities."

During the wildfire, though, Nolan said it was confusing for people - and the province - to distinguish between the local service districts and unincorporated areas.

"Any of us who received the media releases saw that even the province got it wrong with which of the communities were towns, which of the communities were local service districts, which were unincorporated areas," he told CBC Radio's The St. John's Morning Show.

Lethbridge wildfire

To stay in the know, Nolan said, residents of many unincorporated areas look to their neighbouring towns for information.

He said this happened last weekend in the local service district of Lethbridge, where a bark pile ignited a small forest fire.

"Lethbridge has a local service district committee, a Facebook page, those sorts of communication channels," Nolan said. "Neighbouring communities are unincorporated areas out there. So they were looking to Lethbridge to know what to do."

Provincial fire duty officer Wes Morgan told CBC's Newfoundland Morning the Lethbridge wildfire is being held and there is no longer an evacuation order in place, as fire crews work to keep the fire contained.

"They've been out working and trying to create this buffer between the bark pile and forested land," Morgan said.

A sprinkler has also been installed in the area.

"It's just an extra precautionary measure put in place should the fire spread out," he said.

Across the province, many unincorporated areas don't have their own fire departments.

Nolan said this is an issue during emergencies like wildfires because volunteer firefighters from other communities will respond, but they may not have crews knocking on their doors to make sure no one is home during an evacuation.

"They're really left to their own devices aside from the provincial coordination," he said.

Election issue

To improve the situation, Nolan said Municipalities N.L. is trying to make regionalization a provincial election issue.

He said the province could use British Columbia's regionalization model as a blueprint.

"They have regional districts, so that means that the whole province is divided up into regions and regional districts, and those regional districts have boards that have elected representation from the local communities," Nolan said.

Unincorporated areas without a council would have to hold an election so one or two people could sit around that table.

While regionalization allows unincorporated areas to choose services they want from a regional district, safety is top of mind for Nolan.

"The wildfires have brought this to a head again and really show, in terms of emergency management, why this is so important," he said.

Municipalities N.L. proposed regionalization in 2022. The province rejected its proposal, citing low population density and geography as the main issues.

urn:contentItem:6GHJ-22D3-RTP0-W159-00000-00Fires keep burning in western Spain as army deployed2025-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. A020Fires keep burning in western Spain as army deployed

As Spain enters its third week of heatwave alerts, firefighters continue to battle blazes in the northwest and west of the country, with army units deployed to help contain the blazes.

Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said he had held a "co-ordination meeting" at the weekend, as France and Italy sent water bombers to an air base near Salamanca to help with the firefighting efforts.

"The Government continues to work to fight the fire with all the means at its disposal," he said on X.

The most serious forest fires were in the northwest and west of the country, in the regions of Castile and Leon, Galicia, Asturias and Extremadura.

Around 10 roads remain closed across the country, as well as the train line between Madrid and Galicia. Emergency services in Galicia sent alert messages urging residents in dozens of towns to take precautions.

"If you receive this alert: remain calm and read the text carefully," the alerts said. "As the fires spread, avoid all unnecessary travel and stay indoors. If you are outside and have nowhere to stay, move away from the affected areas."

About 3500 military from a special emergency unit were deployed around the country, with some political leaders calling for more.

Alfonso Fernandez Manueco, the centre-right president of Castile and Leon, asked Sanchez's Government "for an exceptional response: we need more army personnel at the disposal of the regions".

Extremadura has also made an official request for reinforcements.

In Spain, firefighting is in principle the responsibility of the regions, with the central government only intervening in the event of a major disaster.

Spain is expected to remain on heat alert until tomorrow, the extreme temperatures having significantly increased the risk of wildfires.

Smoke from wildfires in Spain and Portugal has reached the UK, the country's Met Office reported.

Since the beginning of the year, more than 157,000ha have been reduced to ashes in Spain, according to the real-time map of the European Forest Fire Information System.

-AFP

urn:contentItem:6GSB-P0N3-RRR3-W097-00000-00Hakan Çalhanoğlu And My Lovely Planet Launch The"Çalhanoğlu Forest": 50 Soccer Fields Of Trees In Turkey2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisHakan Çalhanoğlu And My Lovely Planet Launch The"Çalhanoğlu Forest": 50 Soccer Fields Of Trees In Turkey

Link to Story

Turkish football legend Hakan Çalhanoğlu has taken equity in the award-winning Web3 mobile game, recognized by Google Play Store after planting 380,000 trees worldwide.New YorkNY, Sept. 18, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Together, they launch the #PlayForTurkey campaign, where trees planted in the game are also planted in real life.


My Lovely Planet (MLP) , the Web3 mobile game that transforms gameplay into real-world impact, has announced a major partnership with international football star Hakan Çalhanoğlu and his wife Sinem Çalhanoğlu. Together, they are launching the Çalhanoğlu Forest , a large-scale reforestation initiative in Turkey, where every in-game action contributes to planting real trees.

"Football has given me so much, and now I want to give something back, not just to my country, but to the world," said Hakan Çalhanoğlu. "With My Lovely Planet, fans can have fun and directly join me in bringing impact while enjoying the game. Together, we can make gaming meaningful."
My Lovely Planet is no ordinary mobile game. Built by the gaming veterans behind Candy Crush, Royal Match, and Fortnite, and selected by Google (#WeArePlay), the game combines world-class entertainment with a powerful mission: every in-game achievement funds the planting of real trees. Designed to be as addictive and fun as Candy Crush, My Lovely Planet adds a unique twist, players actively contribute to the fight against climate change simply by playing.
"We're building more than a game. We're building a movement where entertainment fuels real-world action. The Kuşadası project is just the beginning - and partnering with Hakan allows us to inspire millions of fans to make a difference, one download at a time," said Clément Le Bras, Founder and CEO of My Lovely Planet .
The Çalhanoğlu Forest: Rebuilding After the Fires
The first project under this partnership will take place on the reforestation site in Kuşadası, Aydın Province , an area devastated by a forest fire on June 29, 2024. The project will be led on site with the Turkish Tohum Association (Tohum Eğitim Kültür ve Doğa Derneği).

Phase 1: Immediate planting of 10,000 saplings financed by Hakan Çalhanoğlu, covering about 50 football fields Phase 2: Now it's your turn! Play the game and plant your own tree alongside Hakan and Sinem Çalhanoğlu's. The more you play My Lovely Planet, the more trees will grow together! Species Mix: To ensure longevity of the trees, only native resilient tree species are planted including Turkish pine (Pinus brutia), oak (Quercus spp.), and select fruit/value trees

Each project is carried out with professional site preparation, active community involvement, and long-term monitoring to ensure lasting success.
Through the #PlayForTurkey campaign, trees planted in the game will result in real trees being planted in the Çalhanoğlu Forest.

On top of that, many more exciting surprises are coming soon, making it clear that gaming can be both fun and meaningful.
About My Lovely Planet
My Lovely Planet (MLP) is a pioneering Web3 Mobile Game that fuses addictive, social gameplay with tangible climate action. Developed by a team of gaming veterans from Candy Crush, Royal Match, and Fortnite, and selected by Google (#WeArePlay), MLP is on a mission to prove that fun and purpose can go hand in hand. Every in-game achievement translates into real trees planted, making entertainment a force for global good.
My Lovely Planet Official Links: Website | Instagram | App Store | Google Play

urn:contentItem:6GRG-FV53-RRYW-539P-00000-00Lightning To Spark More Wildfires In Western US In Coming Decades2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisLightning To Spark More Wildfires In Western US In Coming DecadesEurasia Review

Lightning will ignite more wildfires in the western United States in the coming decades as temperatures increase due to climate change, according to a new study that combined predictions for fire-friendly and lightning-friendly weather conditions.

In the western United States, lightning is responsible for more than two-thirds of the area burned by wildfires, and that number is only going to grow. Starting as early as 2031-2060, the study found essentially all of the western United States, or 98%, will see an increase in days posing a risk for lightning-started wildfires.

Areas that are already at high risk for wildfires started by lightning, such as Oregon, Idaho and Montana, are expected to see the largest increase in overall lightning days, with up to 12 more days per summer by 2060. Some areas, particularly in the U.S. Southwest, like Arizona, are expected to see a smaller increase as they will simply see less lightning.

The new study was published in Earth's Future, AGU's journal for interdisciplinary research on the past, present and future of our planet and its inhabitants.

"The first step was to project lightning," said Dmitri Kalashnikov, research scientist at the University of California Merced and lead author on the study. "The typical climate models don't directly simulate lightning. It's too small a process."

To get around this, Kalashnikov created his own machine-learning models that predict lightning based on the occurrence of weather variables that are typically found in climate models, such as the amount of moisture in the atmosphere. He published the models last year in AGU's Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres.

He combined his lightning models with the Fire Weather Index projections to predict the number of future days when conditions that encourage lightning and fire ignition and spread coincide.

The Canadian Forest Fire Weather Index, created in 1968, measures how favorable the weather is on a given day for wildfires. It keeps track of temperature, precipitation, humidity and other factors that could impact fires. For example, higher temperatures or lower precipitation, especially prolonged, can increase the chances of a fire.

While there have been previous models created for worldwide changes in lightning, Kalashnikov and his team created models that were specifically trained for locations in the western United States and for a closer timeframe. Their models focused on the years 2030 to 2060, compared to previous models that typically only looked at the end of the century.

Using the Fire Weather Index, researchers were able to predict how the number of days that have a high risk of wildfires will change over the coming decades.

The modeling found the northwestern United States was expected to see the largest increase in both lightning days and days with high risk for wildfires. Parts of Idaho, Oregon and Montana saw the largest increase in this cloud-to-ground lightning, or lightning that strikes the ground, which can ignite flammable vegetation. However, due to lesser increases in the Fire Weather Index, these areas will see slower increases in fire risk compared to areas farther south.

The southern half of the western United States still saw an increase in potential fires started by lightning, despite seeing a lower risk for lightning increases than the northern states. The increase is still projected because the entire West saw a general increase in high-risk days for wildfires as temperatures climb and the risk of droughts and heatwaves increase. In the south, Colorado, Wyoming, Arizona and New Mexico projected the largest increases in wildfires started by lightning.

Kalashnikov said next steps could expand what the models include, like bringing in rainfall amounts to differentiate between dry lightning and wet lightning, or lightning that happens with or without rain. This could help differentiate between thunderstorms that pose a risk of wildfires versus heavy-rain producing storms that could create flash flooding.

"You can't help but wonder what the future will look like, especially if you dig in and you realize that there's actually a lot that we don't understand," Kalashnikov said.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5FM3-S5W4-R03G-00000-00First Government Report highlights progress in environmental and sustainable development issues2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:48:19ZLexisNexisFirst Government Report highlights progress in environmental and sustainable development issues


In terms of the environment and sustainable development, President Claudia Sheinbaum highlighted in her First Government Report the restoration of 987 hectares of mangroves, an ecosystem of great importance for the capture and storage of carbon dioxide, coastal protection against hydrometeorological phenomena and the maintenance of fisheries.


fisheries.
He highlighted that the Mexican Government initiated 42 research and technological development projects in the areas of smart grids, asset management, efficiency, energy savings and sustainability, in order to fulfill the commitment to reduce Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, with 35 percent renewable energy by 2030.
He announced the formulation of 26 ecological land-use planning programs in strategic regions of the country with analyses of biodiversity, ecological connectivity, socio-environmental risks and local management capacities.
management capacities.
"Special attention was given to territories affected by high levels of environmental degradation, such as: the Endhó Dam, the Tula River, the Lerma-Santiago System, and the Lerma-Santiago System.
Lerma-Santiago System and the Atoyac Basin.
The management actions addressed the productive use of the land with ecological restoration actions and mitigation of environmental impact," she emphasized.
The President of the Republic revealed that up to June 2025, 95 sawmills and 261 properties were closed in operations against illegal logging.
In addition, forest fire prevention and mitigation actions were carried out, such as the construction of 351.67 kilometers of firebreaks, as well as the training of five thousand 443 people in fire management.
Claudia Sheinbaum indicated that the protection of the vaquita and the Totoaba fish in the Upper Gulf of California was carried out through 293 maritime and land surveillance patrols, as well as 118 inspections at embarkation and disembarkation points and the installation of 89 control and observation posts.
"This resulted in the precautionary seizure of 12 vessels, 19 fishing gear and 103 pieces of Totoaba," he said.
She also pointed out that 311 surveillance patrols were carried out and 889,455 Olive Ridley turtle (Lepidochelys olivacea) nests were protected on nesting beaches located in Oaxaca.
President Claudia Sheinbaum added that in June 2025, the Integral Plan for the East of the State of Mexico was launched, for the construction of a collector in Chalco, which has a length of 1,800 meters and will mitigate the risk of flooding, along with rehabilitation works in 24 wells in the municipality of Ecatepec.
As part of the Acapulco se Transforma Contigo Plan, in Guerrero, 62 percent progress was made in the construction of the Papagayo II Aqueduct crossing over the La Sabana River.
"This work increases the depth to prevent damage due to the effect of erosion of the riverbed," he explained.
Likewise, the Aguas Blancas, El Camarón and La Garita rainwater channels were cleaned and dredged; additionally, 34 percent progress was reported in the cleaning and dredging of the La Sabana River.
Between October and December 2024, the construction and expansion of 161 drinking water and 79 sewerage works were completed, benefiting 239,965 inhabitants of Acapulco.
